RATING: 6.5
A tile-laying/building game with set collection and a "push your luck" aspect.

Each turn you can pick up money, or purchase a tile (specific types of money required),  and hopefully add it to your alhambra or modify your alhambra.  The bonus is that if you pay exact cash, you get another turn, of course if you overpay, you don't even get change back.

Scoring is through majorities in types of building tiles, as well as for each consecutive wall you have on your alhambra.  The "push your luck" comes into play as there are 2 somewhat random scoring cards placed in the deck, and as soon as they appear, you stop everything and score...so do you dare to keep taking money, or do you "waste" that turn modifying your alhambra hoping to put that extra building tile in before the scoring phase?

This game plays 2-6, but realistically, I wouldn't play it with more than 3.  It's actually perfect as a light strategy game for 2-3 players, but above that it gets too random and chaotic.  Luck of the draw with the tiles and money is a factor, but there's enough strategy to overcome this for the most part.  Definitely a good buy if you like tile-layers, and want something different than say Carcassonne.

Own all of the expansions ([boardgame=45358]big box[/boardgame]: [boardgame=9687]Vizier's Favor[/boardgame], [boardgame=13287]City Gates[/boardgame], [boardgame=16494]Thief's Turn[/boardgame], [boardgame=22279]Treasure Chamber[/boardgame], [boardgame=39109]Power of the Sultan[/boardgame]), including the [boardgame=142420]Falconers[/boardgame].

RATING: 7.5
Hmm...there's a lot of both positive and negative things to say about this game, but by and large the positives hold sway.

Positives: it's easy to learn and play, it's attractive to look at and well put together component-wise (as are most Queen games), you can buy lots of variants, it moves along quite quickly with 2, 3 or 4 players, there's a plenty of strategy, a degree of luck to stop it getting stale, the theme and play is quite relaxing which makes for a pleasant evening, you can plan ahead but not so much that it dreis the game up.
Negatives: there's not much player interaction (though beacuse it's light there is a fair bit of heckling and social interplay), some might find that there's too much luck (particularly if someone keeps managing to get two actions by paying the correct cash), if you get a bit boxed in it can be hard to sort that out (but then again good play should mitigate against doing that).

It is somewhat reminiscent of Princes of Florence, but I prefer it to that game as this is less dry and more fun.  The lack of interaction is about the same, but this just seems more of a pleasant way to spend an hour.  It's definitely lighter than PoF, but then again if I want a heavy or heavy medium game, I'd never pick PoF anyway, so in that sense there isn't such a direct comparison - I might well pick Alhambra when a light-medium game is required.

RATING: 6
An interesting game.  The use of the money cards is particularly of note since you get a bonus action (which is pretty valuable) when you spend the exact amount to purchase a structure.  An artificial construct to be sure, but it makes the game infinitely more interesting and provokes more complicated choices.

Even so, seems like there is a fair amount of randomness.  Granted I played a 5 player game which I'm told is more random than one with fewer players, but it just felt overly random.  I think I spent too much purchasing high-cost structures and was unable to purchase as many as I needed.  I'm not sure if that speaks to my lack of experience or the wide range of costs the different buildings have.

An okay game, in my opinion.  I'm glad I got to play it, but it really didn't strike a cord with me.  There aren't any notable mechanics or combinations.  It felt very random.  It also felt like I was perpetually behind because I purchased too many high-cost buildings.  And once you're behind, forget it.  There's no catch up mechanism, or at least no great way to make up the lost ground, particularly as you cannot affect anyone else directly.

I would play this again, but it's not high up on my To Do list.

5/21/10:  I played a 4-player game and enjoyed it.  I'm not quite sure how, but I managed to get a nice wall going and I rode that to victory.  I would definitely play this again.  Rating bumped from 5 to 6.

I know "Alhambra" is one of the greatest games the market offers and it's part of the "Pantheon" of classic boardgames, but for me it's been really hard to put pressure on my friends and convince them to play. The main problem is the unattractive game box (and in general, the game design) that makes it look like kinda boring. I can assure you it's not what it might seem at first sight. The mechanics are great and after the first game everybody was amazed. We're going to play it more often, even if introductory games are not our favourite genre. Hope to be recording new plays very soon!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Alhambra is one of my favorite games yet! The rules are easy to learn and it's intuitive to play. 

However, the point scoring for ties is overly complicated. During the first scoring round, each type of building is scored for the player with the most buildings (of that type). During the scoring round, if there is a tie, then the points are divided among contesting players (rounded down, if necessary). 

The rules are not clear on how to score points if 2 players tie for first place and there are points available for a 2nd or 3rd place finishing. Here's how it's supposed to be handled, according to BGG: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/88797 and http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/32222. I'd prefer that tie scoring is handled like El Grande - if 2 players are tied for first, then the points are split, and then the next placed player gets the points for third place (if applicable). 

Tracked on family list (grooven)! Maybe pick up the deluxe edition?

RATING: 7
I just recently started recording my plays, so the actual play count of this is highly inaccurate. Alhambra was one of the first games I bought along with Carcassonne and Settlers.

I've gone through a few stages with this game. At first, I liked it. Played it with more than 4 people and started to dislike it. It saw the table less and less with the longest time between plays probably clocking in at two months. I pulled it out when my girlfriend was visiting and we tried the two player variant after playing a couple of games of Race for the Galaxy and Ingenious. I fell in love again. Part of the problem with this game is the sweet spot is probably around 3 or 4. With that number of players the planning and decisions come back to the game. With anymore the game is too chaotic and it feels like luck if you are able to buy something on your turn that you need.

Definitely worth it with 4 or less. I'll pass with any more players though.

RATING: 4
Mediocre tile placement game. Supports up to 6 players but the fewer, the better. Easy to teach and play. Gameplay is totally random since you start with random money in random colours and you try to buy random buildings tiles with random costs and random colours and score points at random times (it even rewards lucky players with an extra turn if they have precise the money required for a building) and it gets even more chaotic with more players. Kinda like Carcassone in this aspect. I like the components. I suppose its a nice game for casual players who just want to pass their time chatting around when it is not their turn.

RATING: 10
The ultimate gateway game. It doesn't get any more fun or simple  than this. Three simple actions each turn. Take cash from the bank, buy a building for your Alhmabra or rearrange buildings already in your Alhambra. That's it. But there is a good amount of strategy in this game mixed with the luck of the card draws from the bank. Heavy Eurogamers might think this is too simple and they are probably right. But it is still so much fun. This game ties Ticket to Ride for our favorite gateway game. It is that good.

A sound design, but too much luck in the cards AND in the types of building that come up for auction. RATING: 8.5
I have enjoyed each and every playing of Alhambra.  It has become my first dime of 2005 and will only get more and more playings thoughout the year.   I have played multiple games with 2, 3, and 4 players and feel that it scales extremely well.

Alhambra is a game that offers hand management, city building, tile laying and tough choices throughout.  The "invisible" scoring rounds make for difficult decisions when you start getting close.  "Do I take the money, buy another house or should I move this off my reserve to try and score some points?" "Should I buy a garden that will score me immediate points or a tower that could pay off in the long run?"  "Hmmm...  should I buy the piece to extend my wall or to extend my city?"

I feel that it is themed well and if introduced properly, one can bring the players into the games thematic and playing depths very easily.  It is also very easy to learn and play, while leaving many decisions to allow a certain complexity.  I understand why it won Game of the Year over Puerto Rico, I find it to be a much more accessible game.

RATING: 7
Simple yet very strategic.  I love how you want to do so many different things on your turn, but usually only can afford to do 1 or 2.  Sometimes it can seem to be a bit dull as you sit there building up a hand of cash, but when the right combo of tiles come up you can have a really massive turn.  And it almost seems that there are no bad options since you can use just about any tile to help you or block your opponents.

The 3 separate scoring rounds offers a nice building tension, as things start out small and then build exponentially.  It also makes it hard to predict who is really winning until that final scoring is completed.  Looks like there's some nice potential for the expansions as well.

RATING: 6.5
Great for diehard & casual gamers alike.  Alhambra does not have dice or action cards, but there's enough luck and short-term strategy in the tiles (buildings) & cards (money).   Player interaction in Alhambra consists of observing what other players are collecting, building, etc. and trying to throw a monkey wrench in their plans and/or helping your own position.  This can lead to tough decisions, but the game tends to move quite quickly.  It's fun to watch players walling off areas to score wall points and then trying to figure out how to build more buildings.  The 2-player option for Alhambra is decent, and my casual gamer friends love the game.  ** UPDATE 2008 ** The game suffers a bit with 5-6 players since there are fewer tiles and turns per player and luck plays a bigger role.  I think over-paying is a much more viable tactic with 5-6 players (as opposed to only buying with exact money and getting a rainbow with bad walls).

RATING: 8.2
Fun game that involves resource management.  It also feels very auctiony.  You experience resource anxiety when another player scopes out a particular coin that maybe your saving.

The goals is to aquire various garen plots and construct a vast garden that has certain point garnering qualities.

There is basically resource aquisition that can occur with each turn and then also there is purchasing of a garden tile.  There is usually aquisition of one or there can be both.  There are 3 scoring opportunities in each game and the better you plan for them the more points you gain.

RATING: 5
I played Stimmt So many times before Alhambra and to be honest I don't think Alhambra adds any net value for me. The entire wall building and Alhambra building addition to the basic Stimmt So mechanics seems only to my mind to exacerbate the sheer luck that surrounds the purchasing mechanism.

I'm not sure which I prefer but presently lean in favour of Stimmts So simply because it's simpler with much the same buying and set collecting mechanism and less of complexity hanging from the haphazard buying mechanism. 

At least that's the way it struck me playing with many players. With 2 it may be very different. But with 5 Alhambra is one of those games that leave me free to wander teh games room and chat with other people between my moves because frankly it add the frustrating multiplayer solitaire aspect of the present fashion (think Puerto Rick, Princes of Florence and their ilk) to a buying mechanism that changes so much over the course of 4 intervening players even looking at it after playing is bordering on pointless, I can sit and play my move just as effectively and quickly when it arrives, and move off again to socialize before I have to move again. 

Frankly this whole fashion of little solitaire like constructions on independent boards coupled with mildly interactive resource acquisition mechanisma is of little interest to me and even elss so when the mildly interactive resource acquisition mechanisma vary so much between you turns what goes on there is pretty moot.The most you'd get out of sitting around while others move is maybe biasing your competitive strategy and choice of sets to collect, but frankly a glance around the table just before moving provides the same input.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
My wife enjoys this (big plus!).  A fun game that is not too long, but more of a long filler than a main event.

Update: played 3 times with my wife's family over Thanksgiving.  This was a hit!  I did not expect it to be as well received as it was, especially as a 6 player game, but they all liked it.  I think the fact that turns go by quickly, and that each individual turn is a single decision were both selling points.  The game is still not simple, but neither is it a real thinking game.  There's enough to keep them engaged without overloading.  This is a group that likes to say "I don't want to think while I play a game".  Ah, well - you work with what you have.

As a 6 player game, Alhambra offers relatively little control, because the tiles on offer change quite a bit between your turns.  This makes it a very tactical game, although there is still a layer of strategy in choosing who you will compete for colors with (hint: the person on your left is a good choice).  Most (all) colors will have multiple players buying them.  To some extent, this means that the order in which the tiles and money come out will confer an advantage to some players.  However, I think that in most games, this advantage will not be terribly significant as it will tend to average out over the game.  The player who chooses the right tiles to buy, and the correct timing on hoarding cash verses spending has a greater advantage than that conferred by luck of the draw.  

Overall, this is a light game that, when played quickly, offers a nice experience that doesn't overstay its welcome.  It plays 6, and my wife's family likes it.  That earns it a place in my game closet, even if it's not a personal favorite.

RATING: 7
So far I've only played it two player...

I love the simplicity of the rules (do 1 of three actions), but how with the exact change element you can chain multiple actions on 1 turn.

The overall visual design is really great for getting a feel for where everyone's at and where you'll stand if a scoring card comes up. This could have been a pain, but they did a great job.

I also love the spatial element to this and that it doesn't overstay its welcome. 

My biggest complaint is it is a little drab looking and that the building names (I imagine in order to be language independent) are things like ** or *****. Granted they are different colors, but a little more theme in the building names would have made this a little more immersive and engaging

RATING: 7

RATING: 8
Update July 2010:  Got to play this a couple times this month, for the first time in almost 2 years.  Easy to see why it won the SdJ, though in the 4-player game I played, the other three players didn't like it much.  They were frustrated about the placement restrictions, and the fact that I won in a landslide.  One of the challenges people have is visualizing how the tiles will fit in their Alhambra when the tiles are on the central board, and not the "right way up" to them.  So they were constantly rotating those tiles on the board to see how they would look.  Maybe the solution is for the tiles on the board to always be placed the same way, and for people to organize their Alhambras with the same way being "up" for everyone?  Don't know.  But I want to play this game more.


I like this better than the other multi-currency games I've played, Palazzo & Tower of Babel.  A bit more going on and more interesting tactical tile-laying element.  Definitely want to play this more.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Essentially, in Alhambra you're taking turns to either get money, or spend that money on tiles to build your Alhambra.  Every so often, players will score points based on their Alhambra, scoring points for majorities in different types of rooms as well as the wall sections surrounding the buildings.  So, you must keep an eye on what other players are doing while building in order to maximize your points.

Overall, Alhambra is a very simple game suitable for playing with the family, but is definitely still interesting for gamers as well.  It definitely hits a sweet spot there!

Rating is for a three player game.  My rating goes down 1 point for each player added to the game, since there is quite a bit of luck/randomness with too many players.

RATING: 7
For me, the currency system is what makes this game. Dealing with four different currencies and trying to pay in only exact costs to get those extra turns makes for a really interesting money management game - albeit one that's played more turn-to-turn rather than as a longterm strategy. This turns an otherwise straightforward tile laying game into something unique and memorable.

I rarely play this one, but despite that it's a game I suspect I'd never part with.

The thematic references to many currencies and different architectural styles make this game even more fun.

RATING: 9
This is one of my favorite games. It's easy to teach and it gives you simple but meaningful decisions each turn.  There is very little down time and since there is an ever changing currency and building market, there is no need to plan out more than 1 or 2 turns.  Even then, someone is sure to scoop up that bill or building that you wanted.

The expansions for Alhambra are hit-or-miss.  The nice thing is that they come in packs of 4 and are all optional so you can add the mechanics you like and ignore the rest, or mix and match for variety.

RATING: 7
Easy and fun to play. Not as cutthroat as Carcassonne, which is a good and bad thing in our house - means Alhambra probably won't get as much play as Carc. Then again, I haven't played the 2 player variety.

UPDATE 4/07 - I introduced this to my wife and she told me to buy it before we even finished the game. It's going in our next shopping cart, unless I find a trade here.

It bugs me that some say this is an "Arabic-themed" game. It's not. You might say it's Muslim-themed.. Alhambra was a Muslim outpost palace in Granada, Spain. This is why we have four currencies in the game which relate to currencies which would have been used commonly across Europe and the Muslim world.

RATING: 5
Rated 7 after one play. Solid game. I had heard this described as "best to play as your next Carcassonne," but I don't see the comparison. The tile laying is cool, but this is really hand management with the four different currencies. Nothing totally unique, but this is a solid design, and if my wife likes it, I might pick it up as another "couple's game."

My first play was with six players, which meant that a turn was totally tactical. But I could see where this would be really neat with two or three players... and probably even four. The chance to plan a little more would be nice.

Another play, this time with four. Again, this strikes me as a solid game, but even with four, it's a bit hard to plan. This seems ideal for two or three players. That means, if I'm buying this, it's as a spouse game. It most reminds me of Jaipur... grab cards, and spend cards to nab goods (Jaipur) or tiles (Alhambra). Alhambra adds the fun of building your territory... but takes longer to play, and there seems to be less direct "screw you." A good game, but one that I'm not rushing to buy.

RATING: 10
We loved this from the very first game.  The rules are short, even with lots of examples and illustrations.  However, there are always decisions to make.  You have to balance between short-term points for set collection and long-term points for tile placement.  You have to manage money carefully, as you always need to pay with the correct color of money, and if you pay with exact change you get another turn.  We play 2-player, which uses a dummy player.  The dummy is well thought out and unobtrusive to gameplay.  Although we'd seen alot of pictures of the game, the artwork was much prettier than we expected.  In short, this is a wonderful game.

RATING: 6
Alhambra is like playing Tetris for me. Its more of a mindless activity that I just CAN'T STOP DOING. Actually, that sums up my feelings toward it...but its not entirely accurate on a couple counts.

First of all, I CAN stop playing it. What I mean is that I enjoy it on about the same level as Tetris. But I certainly don't feel like it is a great game. But there is a peacefulness in the rhythm of the game that appeals to me, even if I think the game itself is marginal.

The second thing is that there are SOME decisions to be made...but a lot of it comes down to learning how to see the planning of the placements, and luck of the draw. 

I wouldn't mind playing any time someone wanted to...but I can't see myself suggesting this one.

RATING: 3
Can see why this won Spiel des Jahres, in that tradition this is a medium weight game that would likely work well as a 'cross-over' title. Not sure if this is through good play or good luck, or a combination of them, but I know I was on the roll one game, and most definitely not the other, and I don't think my play style was radically different in either game. One (the first) I won by a landslide, the second I was in last place, and my score was doubled by the winner. Willing to play again, but I would need convincing...for a one hour game there are just so many better options.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Alhambra is one of my favorite games of all time - currently ranked 5th for me in my latest ranking. It is simple enough that I've been able to teach my family, but still deep enough that there's strategy to it. I prefer it as a 3 or 4 player game, but it can go to 6 if you desire. It is a tile-laying and set collection game, which are two of my favorite mechanics. On your turn you can either take money, purchase a tile, or rearrange your alhambra. But if you purchase a tile with exact change you get to take an additional action. So you are often left with a difficult decision of whether you should overpay for a tile, especially if it is critical for your alhambra. Most tiles also have walls that provide additional scoring, but also restrict your placement.

Plays
2013 - 6
2014 - 21
2015 - 4

RATING: 7.75

RATING: 5
Has a black-jack-like quality in that you can do a lot of calculating and memorizing to gain a really small advantage. With 5-6 players, these tasks become more difficult and less meaningful, and even elementary strategies become less feasible since so much will change between a player's turns.

Tile-laying aspect is only sometimes strategically relevant. Timing of scoring cards makes for some really swingy randomness, and it's possible for the second card to still be in the deck at the game's end, which is kinda strange. 

I'd say its a 5-6 as a 3-4 player and a 3-4 as a 5-6 player.

RATING: 4
Components: Soft, easy-to-see artwork and colors. The tiles are top notch, as are the boards. The orange and brown card suits are difficult to distinguish, and the cards could be a better quality. Also, it would be nice to have a track to record the relative quantities of each color tile held by each player, instead of constantly re-counting.

Experience: This game is about one thing only: exact change. The efficiency of buying a tile and also drawing one or more cards is the driving mechanism. The attractiveness and restrictiveness of the tiles belies that this is a set collection game. I prefer the dice spin-off.

First Played: 2004-06-16
Last Played: 2011-03-18
Eagerness to Play Again: Within a year

Plays (3):
3 players: 2
5 players: 1

RATING: 8

The game is very easy to teach and has some good helping of luck with tactical decisions when it comes to buying along with some strategy when it comes to planning your Alhambra.  It all comes together extremely well in a game that plays quickly and has little downtime.  Have yet to find anyone who really didn't enjoy it.

Seems to work well with any number of players, the game just takes on a different feel.

RATING: 6.8
Take money, buy tiles and build your palace by placing the tiles adjacent to your starting tile. Score points by accumulating most tiles of a certain colour, and by building an uninterrupted outer wall. Points are scored two times during the game and at the end of the game. You have 4 spaces where you can store tiles. These can be built later in the game. Best played with a limited number of players. When played with more than 3, luck becomes the most important factor in the game.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of the four classic “pillars of modern boardgaming” (as Will Wheaton calls them).  However, compared to Settlers of Catan, Ticket to Ride or Carcassonne, Alhambra is the often forgotten one.  When “Isle of Sky” came out in 2015, I often heard people comparing it to Carcassonne, but its closer to Alhambra than Carcassonne which shows that no none seems to remember Alhambra much anymore.  I think this comes down to a number of factors.  There has been a total lack of marketing or ongoing promotion on the part of Queens Games and Queens Games’ confusing assortment or versions of this game floating around out there: some versions have names on the tiles; some with just language-independent stars on the tiles; a beautiful ‘family’ edition with the scoring track and tile placement board combined into one; and the original and confusing multi-board version which seems more like a travel-version.  At least in the Anglophone world, there is often the unfamiliar theme (a trip to Wikipedia will greet new players the an explanation of ‘an Arabic name for palace/fortress in SPAIN’) and many players often can’t pronounce or understand the names of the buildings/tiles when they are written out in English.  
Still, the game mechanics are rock-solid after all these years.  There is still luck in the game, but much less so than Carcassonne or Ticket to Ride.  The set-collecting of money cards remind new players of Ticket to Ride while the placement of the individual tiles gives a Carcassonne-style puzzle game to EACH individual player.  Perhaps because it is so under the radar for gateway gamers, they don’t really have any expectations going into it and are very surprised how involving yet streamlined the game is.  There is also the added competitive aspect of having to keep an eye on other player’s boards when deciding if purchasing a building/tile is advantages or not (just like the 2015 “Isle of Sky” game).  There can sometimes be downtime between turns when playing with five or six players, but much less so than Carcassonne because players often already know what they plan to do when their turn comes around and are just breathlessly sitting on edge hoping other players don’t buy the tile they have their eyes on.  
Perhaps because I live in New York City, I thought the re-theming of the game into “New York” some years back was a good idea, but many thought the pasting of the new theme didn’t match well with the mechanics.  The truth is, replacing the walls with streets didn’t make any sense, but you don’t have to live here understand that replacing walls with rivers would have been perfect (we are a group of Islands surrounded by water with rivers and canals often forming boundaries between neighborhoods and boroughs).   
I find the game still goes over very well after all these years and holds up amazingly well. 

Updated Caveat:  This game should not really be played with more than four players, and especially not with six.  With only four tiles up for auction, in a six player game its almost a guarantee that any same tile won’t be around when your turn comes again and thus strategizing becomes next to impossible and the game becomes too random.  Still, a FANTASTIC game with four or three players.

RATING: 9
Alhambra is a really good eurogame. It reaches the 6th player threshold, that provides a good light-soft eurogame for a lot of players. 

In Alhambra, you take only one action per turn of three that are available (just like Ticket to Ride or Terra Mystica), but in a good hand, you can accelerate your game by chain actions (buy tiles at an exact price). 

The game is colorful, easy to play, easy to learn. A must in a familiar game collection. Its mechanics are clear. You take money or you spend money. Spending money is for buying the pieces for your inner garden (the inside of your Alhambra). And the game rewards you for made a good planning in buying and in placing the garden's tiles.

RATING: 5
After first play:
After hearing so much about this game I finally played it and was pretty underwhelmed. Take some money or buy a tile, use exact change and take another turn...Place tile in tableau trying to extend your wall. Rinse and repeat for an hour.

This should either take half the time to play, or include a little more to continue to earn praise. 14 years ago I'm sure it was really cool, but felt like half of a game now.

Pros
+ Simple to learn

Cons
- components aren't anything spectacular
- gameplay is repetitive with too little tension
- game length

Good for a family with kids looking to get into games...But so are so many better games at this point.

Update: after playing this another half dozen times on Boitejux I still feel like for the most part decisions are extremely evident, but player count does matter, I think 3 players is the optimal number. Most of my plays have been with 4 and at that count its too unpredictable and therefore scripted. Not a bad game, just not anything that gets me going.

RATING: 7
I was quite surprised with Alhambra, a game that I admittedly ignored over several years because a) nobody ever hosted it and b) I wasn't going to buy it because everyone calls it a gateway game.  Even still, I found it to be much more strategic than i had expected and it turns out that this is a pretty cool game.  I don't know what the expansions bring, but the base game is a neat twist on the tile-laying genre where players are jockeying for different-colored cards (representing four different currencies) in order to purchase tiles/buildings from the main board.

While the theme is pretty much pasted on, there's still some great decisions to be made here, but with the draw of the cards, there's obviously going to be some luck involved.  Typical Queen production values make it a nice tactile experience as well, but in the end, it's cards and tiles, so nothing entirely too special on that front.

Great game and yes, it's also a great gateway game.  I'm glad I finally got to play it.

RATING: 6

Theme is palace development, but ultimately you are collecting influence (different color types) for scoring. Expansions add/change elements.

RATING: 5
This is one of those tweener games that falls in between family game and gamer's game. These kind usually don't make it to my collection or stay there very long. I've only played the game once, and I enjoyed it well enough (helps if you have a crushing victory in your first game), but this isn't something that I would choose to play or invest in. 

The game offers a nice choice of taking money or buying a tile, and I find the extra action for paying with exact change to be quite clever. The tile placing is mildly interesting except for the walls. I haven't played any of the numerous expansions and have absolutely no idea what they bring to the experience, but I can only assume the game remains in the category of casual gaming. 

That said, it would seem this is an interesting enough game with plenty of variety to be a worthy choice for someone looking for something other than but similar to Carcassonne to play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
An interesting blend of tile purchasing and tile laying made distinct with the twist of needing to use four different currencies.  I've played this with two, three, four, five and six players.  With four, there is a tension (or frustration) in watching your desired tiles or currency cards get snatched up before your turn, leaving sometimes only crappy choices and frequently confounding any long-term strategic planning.  Too much luck, I say; my wife, who seems to almost always win, says no, it's all about flexibility.  

With the two player variation, it becomes a different game, with less competition for tiles and cards and more opportunity to complete your strategies.

Five or six players makes Alhambra impossibly random and with this number, the Vizier's favorite becomes a needed if not necessary expansion and even with it, I would generally rather play something else.

update:  My rating for this game continues to gradually slide.  The more I understand it, the more chaotic and random it seems.  Started at 8 in my early game days.  Dropped to 7 after 10 plays or so.  Down graded to a 6 after my 30th play.

RATING: 7
This game should not be played by more than three players unless you like a lot of chaos. The two player variant with Dirk works very well too. I really like the little game-in-the-game with the wall puzzling. Although very luckbased, Alhambra is really about knowing when to buy tiles without the extra action, mostly in order to screw your neighbour. Even if this happens only once or twice in a game, this decision can often make the difference between win or lose. Like POF, this is NOT a multiplayer solitaire, because if you don't keep track of what the other players are doing you will most certainly get screwed.

RATING: 3
[Set Collection] This SdJ winner is a very dry set-collection game, with a minimum of player interaction. It's also hopelessly random: random money, random tiles to bid on (the combination of which grants effectively random extra turns) and random timing of the scoring rounds. Guess what determines who wins in Alhambra? Ding! The extra turns! That last bit makes this a BAD GAME, a breath away from being broken. I don't see what the accolades are all about. It tries to be Princes of Florence, but lacks the balance granted by the bidding, has almost no control, is without the strategy and depth, and has little player interaction beyond swiping what someone would want, the ability of which is, yep, random. Yuck. ***UPDATE: Well, played my first game of Alhambra F2F and what do you know, it's as boring as it is on BSW. With the extra fiddling with the money and tiles and all, I'd dock it another half-point if its rating wasn't already so dismal. This just goes to show that I can use the SdJ award to determine what games to NOT buy (with the exception of a single aberration in 2000 - the magnificent Torres). Even as family games go, you can do much, much better than Alhambra.

RATING: 9
Tile laying, reminiscent of Carcassonne, but each player creates his/her own city.  Try to build the city with the most of each kind of buildings to score most points.  The money mechanic of getting no change, and getting an extra turn if you pay exact price is great -- because it tempts you to wait until you have exact change, but you know that waiting may cause you to lose what you are trying to buy anyway.  A great game.

RATING: 7.3
Interesting game, and the dummy-player used in 2 player games is an interesting twist. The game lasts a little longer than I feel it should, but the two scoring rounds during the game help add tension and make the time go faster.

However, without the Worker Huts expansion, the placement of each tile in relation to others is largely meaningless. Having 3 purple tiles spread across your Alahambra is equivalent to having them clustered in a purple area if you can line up your walls correctly.

In all, it's a fun game but I like Granada slightly more.

RATING: 7
Played for the first time at the Oasis of Gaming in 2002 and said: 
"Not sure this is one of my favorites. It has a lot going for it, but there is also an awful lot to think about and keep up with. It will take more plays for this one, but so far doesn't push my buttons. I give it a "7" which is considered "above average" for me, but not "Good" (reserved for 8's). Maybe further plays will change my mind."
Well...further plays (4 total) have changed my mind. I bought the game nearly a year later (4/1/04), and played it 2-player on 4/22/04, and two more times thus far in May '04. The second play was MUCH better as I understood what I was doing. We played it 2-player this time and its stock really shot up. I really do like this one. Want to play again. 
After 4 plays - I now rate it an 8.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I'm glad I got to play again for a second time recently because I recall not quite liking the game the first time I played years ago. Alhambra has some definitely neat things going for it. The trade off of taking less money for more opportunities to receive additional actions is great and I can't think of another game that does it quite like this one. And turns are simple and rules aren't heady, so in that regard it works very well. I still don't think I love the tile placement aspect of it though. The walls are there to put constraints on the players and also award good planning, but I found it more of a frustration and less fun than I would have hoped for. I also don't like that you can't ever really work towards a tile in the immediate as it can easily be gone from the purchasing board when your turn comes up. Again, this is where the added flexibility of smaller denomination cards comes in (so you can jump to another tile) but the tile display is usually different when it gets back to your turn.  All you can do is hope a good tile turned up or theres a money card worth your time. But your tile options often feel more random than an intriguing tactical decision. Pushing the "randomness" aside and you're still left with an interesting game of figuring out when to hold off and when to buy and when to exchange and so on. I would play again. I just don't know if I found the game "fun". But I do recognize the quality of the design and I think there is stuff in here to explore. So again, I would play it again to see if I could wrap my head around it better.  And good to note: the 2-player rules work very well!

RATING: 8
We also own the Vizier's Favor and the Magical Buildings expansion.  All cards are sleeved.

We had the Anniversary addition, but didn't like the board so we crafted some replacement components using geek-provided images.  No box - this one is a keeper.

Rating is for 2 or 3 players ONLY(!), unless you include the "Vizier's Favor" expansion.

My wife and I really enjoy this as a 2 or 3 player game. She ALWAYS gets the longest wall!  I love her for it.  One time her Alhambra was completely enclosed at the end of the game.  She's such a cutie!  This game is AWFULL with 4 or more players.  Your ability to defer opportunities with some hope of them still being extant on your next turn is greatly reduced, thus taking away much of the game's tension and enjoyment.

The Vizier's favor does help fix the 4+ player problem by adding the ability to interrupt someone else's turn.  With 4 or more, this is a necessary expansion.

RATING: 9.5
Basic Alhambra acquired December 2005. (As of November 2006) We have played this game only a few times, and everyone seems to like it. I have never done well at it, for some reason, but I still suggest playing it occasionally. The game is easy to learn and provides some good challenges. As is typical in this type of game, you can't do as many things during your turn as you wish to do, so decision-making is critical. I believe this will continue to be a popular game in our family group.

May 2009 -- This is one of the family's favorites at this time. We play it fairly often, and we are considering trying one or more of the expansions.

October 2009 -- We purchased the Big Box with all expansions and are gradually trying them out. We have added several extensions permanently to all our games, including the coins, thief cards, diamonds, money exchange cards, master builder cards, and vizier. We have enjoyed City Gates and City Walls, and are hoping to enjoy other extensions. -- We gave the basic game to our daughter, son-in-law, and grandchildren.

RATING: 7
I don't know what to think. The game is original and neatly put together. The rules are rather simple (maybe with few exceptions). The pieces and the mechanics fit the theme (if you can imagine building a palace by placing the tiles). The thought that bothers me is the scalability. With 2 players it was achieved by adding a virtual player which is the least elegant way I have ever seen. It's similar to the other games by Dirk Henn - Atlantic Star or Shogun - and I didn't like it there as well.

Maybe I will get used to it - time will tell. But so far 7 is the highest note I could give Alhambra.

RATING: 6.5
Rating is for 2-player with Worker's Huts and Camps expansions. With 3, rating drops to about 6. With 4, to about 4.

Played exclusively  2-player. Even with just one other real opponent (not counting phantom Dirk), luck of the draw looms large in the base game. My highest scoring game, 155 points, was achieved by simply buying for exact cost when possible and drawing a good balance of card colors otherwise. And never using the reserve.

After one 4-player game, think I'll keep this solely as 2-player. Far too little control otherwise.

Playing with Worker's Huts and Camps expansions makes this more of a real game.

RATING: 7
I would like so much to actually play this in its physical form again (I just played it once, then only online).

It's the epitomized Euro: little secret information, scoring on set collection and majority. Normally not my genre, but this is great fun.

You buy a building or get money (chosing from an array for both). Buildings and money come in 4 suites, if you pay the exact price for a building you get a bonus action.

As simple as that, you collect building and score points based on having the most of them.

On top of that, buildings can have 1,2,3 or 4 "outer walls", which you need to combine in your own Alhambra (emir's palace).

Fun, would like to try it again

Great Game! tile laying and building within the economic constraints of the money in your hand.  very simple to learn. no social interaction but it isn't a screw your neighbor type of game either.  you have alot of choices in the game, yet arent bogged down by analysis-paralysis.  play your own game, but keep track of what the others are doing because you are competing for the points of the tile types.  This is a very visually appealing game!  I think this is the next game to introduce to non-gamers after you have them hooked on Carcassonne.  It even has symbols to help color-blind gamers!  I look forward to playing this game again.  When I do I am sure my rating of it will go up.

RATING: 7
Pleasant light-middleweight offering for those who don't mind quite a lot of luck.  The tile-laying subgame is an excellent feature that adds another layer to the decisionmaking.  Seems almost like an Alan Moon homage with the randomly-shuffled wertung cards, the drafting mechanism, and the majorities in various sets of cards.  I wouldn't care to play with any more than 4 players, and the game is only enjoyable if players move through their turns quickly.  I actually like it best with two players and open money holdings.  Great visual appeal makes Alhambra a more gratifying experience than predecessor Stimmt So.  However, the inability to intelligently plan ahead means that both games are better configured for families than for gamers.

RATING: 8
This game is a little dry, but I still enjoy it. The choices are few and simple yet so difficult to make. Trying to decide when to buy buildings without exact change is brutal yet so important. This game with 3-4 players requires precision, building your city to maximize your points for the amount of money you spend and the number of tiles you lay. Placing tiles while balancing the benefit of long walls with the danger of limiting your options gives Alhambra a 'Carcassonne-esque' element. 

With larger numbers the Vizar, which comes in the first expansion, is necessary, but you can just look up the rules and use a makeshift piece (like the additional colored disc for each player).

I need to try more expansions but they are so expensive ($25 apiece, really?!).

RATING: 5
The "four currencies" thing was genuinely surprising; I figured any core mechanic from a beloved gateway game this old would be familiar to me. I think I like it?

Mostly, though, this has a few ideas I liked in Quilt Show, but where Quilt Show has its (maybe too sudden?) simultaneous guesses about how big a quilt other players will make this time, Alhambra has the downside of many area control games: perpetually rechecking how you're doing against each opponent in each of six areas. I could do without that.

But it's cozy, and I'll take it over Ticket To Ride any day.

RATING: 7
Easy to learn, quick to play and has some tactical decisions to make in order to advance your own position or screw another player. It doesn't have the depth of some other Euros but my regular gaming friends outside the club are relatively new to gaming and so this seemed like an ideal game.

Having played a 6 player game with my friends I stand by my initial thoughts on this game despite a slight problem of keeping everyone's attention on the game during other people's turns. I think this game would work better with 3 or 4 players as there would be less downtime and more opportunity to make tactical decisions.

RATING: 9
A Christmas present from some good friends, this is an excellent light-euro game featuring card-drafting, tile purchase and tile-laying. Highly deserving of it's Spiel des Jahres award in 2003.

The slight unpredictability of when the scoring cards will come out, gives the game an added level of tension, and whilst there's no direct player interaction, there's plenty of ways to indirectly influence other players by your card choices and tile purchases. It's particularly satisfying to hear someone moan when you purchase the tile they had their eye on.

Plays well with 3 to 5 players, but not as good with 6 as there's a lot of down time and you have much less control. The official 2-player variant is playable, and pretty good.

2011-01-20 Upgraded my rating to a 9 after a number of plays recently. Excellent hand management and set collection game, with an spatial element.

RATING: 4
(1 play) A bland, inoffensive game of buying tiles to place in your separate playing board, that you build up using the tiles.  Players get one action per turn: buying a tile, drawing cards (used to buy tiles), or rearranging your playing board.  If you pay the exact amount for a tile, you get another action.  Players earn points during scoring rounds by having a majority of tiles in a given colour.

This is another one of those dull Euro games where everybody does their own thing and there's no real way to affect someone else other than buying a tile they may want.  At least it's short, so it's an OK filler while you're waiting for someone else to finish a game so you can move on to something deeper.

RATING: 7
This is an excellent gateway-type game and belongs right up there with things like Ticket to Ride and Settlers of Catan. Very simple rules structure, but really difficult decisions. Both strategic and tactical play are rewarded, there are a few different reasonable strategic paths to victory, and turns are very fast. Competition occurs through trying to maintain majorities, not by interfering with other players. In some ways it surprises me that this game didn't become more popular than Carcassonne, but I guess it was a few years behind.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Plays up to 6 players, and easy to teach.  Part of the strategy is to count how many buildings each player has, and how many are left in the bag, and plan to compete appropriately.  You can't win points in all the colours, so you have to pick your battles.  And of course, long walls have a huge effect on your score and can win you the game.  Unfortunately, there is a lot of luck of the draw -- if you are lucky enough to be offered exactly the right building at the right time, or if you can buy many buildings for exact change, you will end up with more buildings, and more chance to win categories (and hence the game).It's very frustrating to play this game with 6 players -- it's all about luck of the draw, which makes it hard to plan.  If you don't happen to have enough money cards, you can draft money in a colour that you think you can win with exact change... but then there are 5 players who can buy that tile before it gets back to you.  So either you over-pay for the new tile (and give up the chance to draft new money cards), or you draft money and hope that you can get an exact payment next time around.

A friend mentioned that he won't play this game with more than 3 players.  That could be a restriction that makes this game acceptable to me, and perhaps have it see the light of day more often!

RATING: 6
[Initial Impression: 7]
Spatial visualization skills are needed to work on the game's puzzle-like quality, which involves setting up your Alhambra to easily be able to add new tiles while simultaneously maximizing the wall around its perimeter. I sometimes find myself entering a near-meditative state while crafting an efficient Alhambra. The other aspect of the game involves knowing which tiles to buy to aid yourself and which to buy to block your opponents. Tension mounts as opponents buy the tiles you were hoping for and then reveal a tile for your dominant currency. Overpaying for a good tile now may leave you unable to pay exactly (thus gaining an extra turn) for another good tile later.  The two-player variant is surprisingly good, partly because it ramps up direct competition for tiles and partly because it is difficult to win against the dummy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
An excellent tile laying game. This game involves planning where you want to lay your buildings around your fountain (city centre). Walls must be adjacent to each other and you score point for each wall touching each other.

ON YOUR TURN : do one of two things. 

Option 1:
Collect cards with total value up to 5. It could be 3x 1 value and 1x 2 value or 2x 2 value and 1x 1 value. Or it could be 4 and 1. The rule is you can take and number of cards up to the total value of 5. You may also take 1 card of any value if it exceeds 5. There are 4 colours of coins to collect from Orange, Blue, Yellow and Green. 

Option 2:
Pay cost of tile laying on board equal or more of the value stated on the tile. If the value was paid exactly, take an additional turn and you may purchase another tile or take coin cards.

While purchasing tiles, you have an option to place that tile in the reserve to be placed onto your city later on.

Option 3: 
Remodel or swap tiles in your city. Sometimes it can be advantages but in most cases it takes up an entire turn therefore, planning is very critical in this game.

Great game for beginners and I think I will recommend this game to anyone who is new in boardgaming.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
A fun, lightly-themed game with a bit more strategy than most people play it with. Almost everyone I've played this game with gets caught up in purchasing tiles with "exact change" - which is a great bonus - but then they are left with a bunch of the same-colored tiles and I can score some quality points (bwahahaha!). 

I think the game works the best with 4 players. There are a few quirks to this game: (1) the scoring system seems odd. I am not quite sure why yet... the first time I played this game (with 4 players) the 1st place and 4th place people were only 5 points apart (tight game)... then the second time I played the 1st place person won by 40+ points... I like the longest wall concept - it seems very 'Settlers'; (2) the reserved spaces are rarely used - the game doesn't require too much foresight when constructing your alhambra and, therefore, doesn't require much waiting-for-the-right-tile (unless you are a perfectionist); (3) back to the scoring: I think the "longest wall" is worth too much when compared to having the most of a certain type of building... maybe that's the weird thing about scoring. I don't know.

RATING: 6
This is a fun little collection game, with the added complexity of having to fit your tiles in a cohesive order.  I like it better than Princes of Florence, and feel it has slightly higher replayability.  

The expansions (of which I own many) are hit-and-miss.  Some add to the game, while others clutter it.  

Down sides are few, but significant.  The game can feel like parallel solitaire as each player has limited effect on others.  It is also hard for the directionally impared, as some tiles can be impossible to fit.

RATING: 10
Alhambra is an absolute blast!  I am not usually a big fan of lighter games, but for some reason, Alhambra is lots of fun.  It is easy to teach and play, and yet there is definitely strategy involved.  If you like building games, Alhambra is highly recommended.  It is one of the few games my mother actually will play and enjoys.  It is also a great two player game with the two player variant. . . . I've played almost all of the expansions (having got the Big Box) and they add a lot of fun and variety to the game.  It has taken 89 games for me to burn out a little on this one.  I'm going to let it sit for a few months and then bring it out again.  A brilliant game.

RATING: 10
Alhambra is a relatively easy gateway game focusing on market manipulation with a very satisfying puzzle-like tile laying element. For me, this beats Carcassonne in the tile-laying genre simply because the scoring is much more intuitive, and the ability to plan and purchase tiles allows for more satisfying long term strategy. 

A huge bonus is how well this game plays with 2 players. I was afraid the "dummy" third player would feel like a cheap crutch, when in fact the "Dirk" player (we call them the Silk Merchant) allows for some interesting manipulation by both opponents.

I had my eye on the Big Box expansion for years before finally pulling the trigger, and boy am I glad I did. The base game is wonderful, but it really shines when you add in the variety of expansions which give it endless replayability.

RATING: 5
Simple tile laying game.  Players must maximize their score by effectively managing the 4 different denominations of currency and choosing tiles wisely and placing them in the best spot on their Alhambra.  The game seems a bit too random to me for me to really enjoy it.  Maybe if I played it more, I would understand its nuances better and appreciate the game more.  However, I feel at this point I have played it enough to declare that it is too simple and random for me and I find Alhambra to be a boring game.  You will never hear me request Alhambra with so many other awesome games to play in its stead.

RATING: 6
Solid set collecting game.  Aim of the game is to collect sets of coloured building tiles which are added to your Alhambra according to some simple placement rules, points scored based on who has the largest set of each colour.  Extra mechanic from wall section drawn on tiles which, if lined up, score extra points.  This adds some important decision making into the tile choices, and doesn't really allow you to simply take the most valuable tiles arbitrarily.

I would say this is a family-friendly game, and one that children would learn quickly.  Works for 2 - 6, but 2 player game requires slight alteration where some tiles are given to an imaginary player who competes for points.  This is slightly weak but allows the game to work for 2 people which is useful.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 2
The only reason this doesn't get a 2 or less it it *might* work better with fewer players....we played with 5.  First of all, 2 players started with 40% more money (28) than the rest of us due to the broken money mechanic at the start of the game.  Exactly how is it fair to give a player a turn (or two) advantage just because the money they got dealt was 19, and then they get a 9 for their last card?  Oh, and don't get me started on the money itself....4 different kinds.  I never even had a chance to get any green money the entire game.  Not to mention the walls basically make it a totally random game...you *might* have the right amount of money to get that tile, but it probably doesn't fit your palace.  And then to give somebody a big advantage to get extra actions just because they start with more money than you is a snowball.  We were wiped clean by the two with 28...they always seemd to have the right amount,  starting at the beginning, so they got to refill their hands with money right after spedning, ,while the other three of us rarely got to do the exact thing.  How did this get the SDJ?  BROKEN

RATING: 8
The ideal gateway game; very easy to learn game with only a few options to decide between each turn, yet there is some depth there for more experienced players. 

Alhambra has a similar card collecting style to Ticket to Ride, but to me is better for beginners because your goal is flexible and open-ended, so it's more forgiving, you don't need to hoard cards and there's lots of variety from game to game.

The point system means everyone is usually able to pick up points regardless and also leads to some amusing outcomes (draws). Building your own Alhambra gives you a tangible achievement to invest in. This game also works well with 3 to 6 players without really changing the game length.

RATING: 6
A dry tile layer that doesn't do anything devastatingly wrong but unfortunately nothing too terribly right either. No interaction and big luck factor here ensuring a lack of control will turn off many people and this really limits any kind of strategizing albeit a little planning is possible to overcome some of the luck and also for optimizing your point scoring opportunites. 

The game is mostly about reacting to what other players are doing and playing the odds a little with that and the tiles to score the most points. The 2 ways to score is the strength of the game, also competition for the cards adds a little tension. The fun factor is  definitely missing in this game though and forget about playing with more than 2 or 3; 4 or more would be way too chaotic and there are much much better games with those numbers.

Initial Rating: 6.5 (September 2011)

I don´t remember why (I forgot the setup rules) but I feel the initial setup is very unfair. Alhambra is not a bad game but not one for me, it is too light and takes too long for my taste. If a game is going to take more than 90 minutes I want it to be more complex, also it has a very high luck factor (which I dislike). 

This is a fine game to introduce to non-gamers, but there is something about the tile placement mechanic that bothers me (I don’t like Carcassonne either).

On the good side, the game is beautiful.

I don´t want to play this game anymore but I might play once in a year.

RATING: 5
I've only played this once, so take it with a grain of salt. The game was a 6 player game and was enjoyable and fast. I didn't feel that I had all that much control though. I DID enjoy the game, but it felt fluffier than I'd expected. In the 6 player game, there wasn't much thought involved; it boiled down to: ok, what's available to buy now? If I could afford it and needed it, I'd buy it if I wasn't over paying buy much, if I couldn't afford anything on the board, I'd draw money. That really was about it.With less players, you would have more chances at buildings available to buy each round, with 6, it could change drastically.All this said though, I did enjoy it and would play it again. It was a nice game, quick, and fun to play. It's a good level of game for any type of player.I would like to try it a bit more to see if my rating changes. I really think it may go up with less players, but 6 certainly worked well and wasn't broken.I did not feel that I was influencing the game in any way, nor did I feel able to catch or hamper other players aside from taking a building they may have wanted or matching them (perhaps surpassing them) in a building color.Each round (there are 3) ends with scoring. In some ways it's akin to El Grande or San Marco with the Victory Points being shared out: if you have the majority of a color in a round you get the Victory Points listed on the score card. If 2 or more people have the majority of a color they share the Victory Points out amongst each other. In the 2nd round there are points if you have the most of a color and then the player with the 2nd most of a color will score. The third round spreads the Victory Points out to 3 levels deep in color majority Victory Points: The Most, Runner Up, and the Bronze Medalist.You also score points each round for each connected segment of a wall in your garden.It's a good game, but with my one playing at 6 players, it did not wow me.

RATING: 7.5
One of my favorite family games. Nice pieces and smooth play. Its constituent elements aren't original (at root: the traditional card game of [gameid=15889] + Carc)--but it all works. You can tell it was designed by an expert. I love the increasing tension as game progresses, since each scoring round has exponentially higher points and builds on what you've constructed previously. I love the tiles get increasingly harder to place as game goes on and the points-at-stake go up so the end is tense. I like how you know approximately when scoring will occur--but not exactly. Wife likes a lot (bonus 1/2 pt). We were surprised the 2p version works so wonderfully; it's actually more interactive since you can actually strategize what cards you take from tableau, and you may donate tiles to the dummy-hand and thereby screw-your-neighbor.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
It seems to be conventional wisdom on BGG that Alhambra is a similar game to Carcassonne. I disagree completely - Alhambra is all about acquiring the right tiles, the actual placing of the tiles borders rarely requires much thought. Meanwhile, tile placement in Carcassonne is the very core of game. Alhambra is all about maximizing your own score. Carcassonne, if played competitively, is extremely confrontational - it's often in your best interests to stick it to your opponent rather than try to increase your own score.

What Alhambra does feel similar to, in my opinion, is Vikings.

RATING: 8.5
As a result of my family loving the dice game so much, I figured I had to get my hands on a copy of the original.

Picked up a copy of the gold edition in a math trade in exchange for Agricola, and is certainly one of my favourite trades. I seriously underestimated how well this game would be received. I had been fully prepared to deal with my mother and my wife preferring the dice game, but the subtleties of the game have won out over the (in comparison) static nature of the dice game.

Furthermore, having introduced the game at our first game night with another couple, they also loved the game and made hints at having to pick up a copy for themselves.

The fact that everyone who's come in contact with it so far has really liked it, combined with the opportunity to change the game with expansions, makes me think we'll be enjoying Alhambra for a while to come.

RATING: 5
I'm looking to play this a few more times.  I feel like I'm missing something - the game seems overly simplistic to me, though others' comments lead me to believe that I owe this game a few more plays.  

Update: I actually enjoy this more with 2 players with the dummy player "Matt".  I would guess that the enjoyment goes down as you add more players.  6 player games involve too much waiting, and the market is composed of completely different tiles by the time it's your turn again.  Compounded with the longer playing time, I would be very hesitant to play this with more than 3 players.

Further update: after acquiring the expansions in a trade, they add a little spice to the game and are interesting to experiment with.  I think that Alhambra makes a good gateway game due its short play time and relatively simple choices to make.  This is a solid game that doesn't achieve greatness, but is pleasant, almost relaxing, to play.

Update, 3/15: Supplanted by the card game (Stimmt So) version, which shows how superfluous all the changes were. Traded away.

RATING: 8
One of the first more serious games I own and play (this is shown by the fact, that my rating for the weight of the game was "Medium Heavy"), so it will always be a little bit special. On the other hand, the game is pretty interesting. You have to always think at least about two things: which buildings you are trying to collect to be the majority owner and how to build the longest wall possible. For some reason, wall building is the weakest part of my play. Moreover, players have to decide if to buy a building paying the exact amount and to get an additional action or to overpay for a building in order not to miss the opportunity to obtain it. The most important thing is to not include too many expansions in order not to complicate the game too much.

Vienas iš pirmųjų rimtesnių žaidimų (tai rodo ir tai, kad prie žaidimo svorio buvau nurodęs "Medium Heavy"), todėl visada man bus kiek ypatingas. Kita vertus, visai jis įdomus. Reikia nuolat mąstyti bent apie du dalykus: kokių pastatų daugumą nori surinkti ir kaip pastatyti kuo ilgesnę sieną. Kažkodėl būtent sienos statyti man dažnai nesigauna. Taip pat reikia galvoti, ar pirkti už lygiai ir gauti dar vieną ėjimą, ar permokėti, bet nepraleisti progos nusipirkti. Svarbiausia nepadauginti papildymų, kad nepasidarytų per daug painu.

RATING: 8
I have never won a game of Alhambra. I have only played four or five games of it at all, mind you, but I haven't won a single one, and I still like it quite a bit.

UPDATE: I have won two games of Alhambra now!

The mechanics are simple, it is not overly stressful, and I always love the feel of crafting or creating something. Alhambra does that last bit quite well, even if the aesthetics of a design are a distant third in importance to the length of the walls and the quantity/diversity of the districts. I think that it has a perfectly manageable level of luck, and—getting back to my first line—it is very good to play with non-gamers both because of the rule simplicity and because somehow the people I have introduced it to have all turned out to be really good at it.

I like Alhambra, and I think that it is a marvelous game to work people up to heavier things later on.

RATING: 5.5
I don't get why everyone loves this game so much.  It's cute and easy to learn, but not much else.

My feeling was that there was always one obvious best choice on a given person's turn.  The variability was in the luck of what money/tiles were available rather than in player strategy choices.

The theme is also tacked-on.  I know, Eurogame blah blah, but since I found it lacking in strategic challenge, it's too bad the theme couldn't pick up the slack.

I'm hanging on to it because I know plenty of people who would like a game that doesn't require much decision.  It's a good "gateway drug" in that sense.  But personally, I won't be playing it much.

RATING: 9
The Good:  Good strategy game, but not too heavy for the family to enjoy. Good tough decisions to be made. The two player variant is actually very good.

The Bad: Plays very differently with 2 than with 5. More players makes it more difficult to plan ahead. Be aware that this is not a quick filler game (at least on the first play), as it took us 2 hours with 3 new players. However, the time does drop somewhat with experienced players. Depending on the players you may have some downtime between turns.

RATING: 8
I have always wanted to learn and play this game!  I was excited when I was able to!  A straight forward tile placement game with interesting buying and auction mechanics.  You never know when you will be scoring points in a round, the tension of a round ending is always there!  "Do I buy that building, and do I have exact change to buy it so I could have another full turn?"  Scoring is easy to figure out, and get better over time.  Although this was only my first game, all three of us were ten points apart!  Granted I probably didn't use certain actions when I should up but, it's ok!  A great game!

RATING: 8
Full of agonizing decisions, and full of beautiful bits. This was an instant winner in our household, and has been well-received by non-gaming extended family members. It has the right blend of randomness and strategic planning for my taste. It can be tense on almost every turn. It works better for 2-3 players- at 4, you spend too much time studying tiles and cards that won't likely be available on your next turn, and waiting patiently while someone else agonizes over what to do. I like it best for 2 (with the 3rd dummy player- usually Kipper, our cat who likes to try stealing the score markers/napping on my wife's palace complex).

Played it once so far. Was a nice game.

You can buy tiles and build your city. There are always 4 tiles to buy and after one was bought, another one is added from the tile-deck. So you never know which tiles are coming. Other players will buy tiles that yourself would like to have.

I think there are also some great expansions that add lots of possibilities and replay value.

The artwork is ok, could be a little better maybe. I'd say if they would release it in 2016 they would make it a little better, since nowadays lots of games have awesome artwork and components. But it is from 2003 where players were used to common medium artwork.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
In Alhambra, players are acquiring buildings to be placed within their Alhambra complex.

On a player's turn, a player may take money from the open money market, purchase a building from the building market, or engage in construction and re-construction projects with buildings that have been placed in the player's reserve. The game rewards efficiency, as when a player purchases a building from the market for the exact amount of money, the player may take another turn.

Players with the most buildings in each of the six building types score in each of the scoring phases, and points are awarded for players' longest external "wall" section within their complex. The game ends when the building market can no longer be replenished from the building tile supply, and there is a final scoring, whereupon the player with the highest score wins.

RATING: 4
A játék jó, gondolkodós, de több dolog is akad benne, ami nem tetszik. Egyrészt, hogy mintha nem lenne elég interakció benne, mert mi szinte szótlanul játszottuk végig. Igaz, közben végig nagyon gondolkodva, hogy mit is érdemes csinálni, szóval nem unatkozva szótlanul, hanem a gondolkodásba elmerülten szótlanul. Aztán szerintem hátrány az is, hogy bár a kézben lévő lapok elvileg titkosak, de ha valaki jegyzi, akkor mégis tudhatja őket, hiszen látja, hogy ki milyen lapot húz fel vagy dob el. A játék maga nagyon egyszerű, és elég jó is, épp kellő mélységű ahhoz, hogy kellemes legyen: sem túl felületes, sem nem veszik el a szabályok bonyolult útvesztőjében. A játékelemek kidolgozottsága majdnem kiváló, csak egy bajom van vele: a barna és a lila lapok színe túl hasonló, nehéz őket egyetlen pillantással megkülönböztetni.

Update: A negyedik játéknál már tökéletesen ismerve és alkalmazva a szabályokat eljutottam oda, hogy ráérezzek a játék ízére. Tetszik, szívesen játszom vele! 7.2 -> 7.4 pont.

Update2: Annyira nagyon azért nem jó ez a játék, legalábbis két játékossal. Oké, figyelni kell arra, hogy minél több épülettípusból nekem legyen a legtöbb, vagy legalább egálban legyek valakivel, meg hogy a falam is szép hosszú legyen, esetleg hogy mások elől elhúzzam a számukra értékes épületeket, és hiába tűnik ez épp elégnek, de a játékosok között még sincs direkt interakció, gyakorlatilag szótlanul, mechanikusan le lehet játszani az egészet.
Több játékos esetén már nagyobb lehet a harc az épülettípusokban többséget szerzésért, ugyanakkor mire rám kerülne ismét a sor, már jó eséllyel felhúznák a kiszemelt épületet, szóval a tervezhetősége meg csökkenne. 7.4 -> 7.1 pont.

Update3: Nagyon hiányzik a direkt interakció a játékból. Nem lenne rossz, de ezt túl súlyos hibának érzem, egyszerűen nem elnézhető. 7.1 -> 6.6 pont.

Update4: mégis szép emlékként él bennem a játék: 6.6 -> 6.8 pont.

Update5: Újrapontozom a játékokat aszerint, hogy melyikkel mennyire szívesen játszanék mondjuk ma este. Ez alapján: 4

RATING: 7
This is a nice gateway game.  It feels a little like a cross between [GAMEID=9209] (in the money selection option) and [GAMEID=822] (in the tile placement), but introduced some new elements as well.  The wall bonus was also clever---it was important to build the longest wall to get points, but it was self-balancing since you could very easily cut yourself off and prevent any further expansion.  

It was also a great two player game.  We actually recently played it with three and actually preferred the two player game.  Unlike a lot of multiplayer games that also work with two, [GAMEID=6249] is the rare game that has [i]more[/i] strategy in the two player game.  Although much maligned, the dummy player Dirk works brilliantly.  He's not really a true player---think of him as a new away to affect the other player by serving as a tile dump.  For example, to prevent your opponent from getting second place points, you could buy Dirk tiles to move them down to third place.  The random tiles that Dirk gets also serves to slightly randomize the game to keep you on your feet on what the more valuable tile distributions are.  In fact, we found that the two player game without Dirk was almost broken---at one point I had already bought the majority of purple tiles, so it was pointless for me to buy any others.  Similarly, it was pointless for my girlfriend to buy any more purple tiles since she was guaranteed second place.  Guess what was available in the quarry?  Four purple tiles.  In contrast, the existence of Dirk would provide tension for whether she would get the second or third place points.  In addition, the [i]point differential[/i] between any of the colored tiles was the same, so in the zero sum two player game, it just didn't matter which colors you got, just as long as you had the majority in more of them.  With Dirk, it's totally different.

With more players, I can see how the game would bog down and get too chaotic since to form any long term strategy.  Probably best with two.

Funny, unlike [GAMEID=822], we really haven't had the urge to try any of the expansions...

Full review:  [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/194867]A Newbie Couple's Review of Alhambra[/url]

RATING: 4
I've only played this on BSW, and it was the third BSW game that I learned.  When I first played it, I thought it was a nice blend of strategy and fun, you know, decent filler.  Over time, though, it has just slid down my list of games that I want to play.  I've just learned more games that are the same weight but seem to be more rewarding such as Ra, St. Petersburg or Sticheln.  I now haven't played it in months.

UPDATE: Now that this is no longer on BSW, I doubt I'll ever play it again.

UPDATE: A friend got this for Christmas unexpectedly, returning it to my gaming consciousness. It even seems to be a bit better than I remembered it as being. Probably best with 4, with the chaos level growing rapidly out of hand above that.

Not my thing, per se, but better than average.

UPDATE: Ahhhhhhhh! [i]There's[/i] the annoying screwage by random factors that I remember. Down a point. Inoffensive, but rather too long for what it is.

UPDATE: Burning out on this rapidly. It's in heavy rotation, and much loved by the rest of my (small) game group. I have to admit that I really want the new game shine to wear off before I am permanently soured on it. 4, at least for now.

RATING: 6
Pretty simple to learn and I like that the multiple dimensions to think about through the interweaving of wanting majority of certain building colors, the wall bonuses, and trying to chain card drafting set collection. The two scoring periods throughout the game and that things don't refill till the end of the turn also makes it feel like you can't just hoard cards like crazy and basically split the game into two halves, as can sometimes be the issue of ticket to ride against new players. However, I didn't like how tactical the game felt, with the board states that are shared by players (tiles to be bought and cards to be drafted) possibly completely changed by the time it gets back to your turn. Because of that, I can't imagine playing this with more than 3.

RATING: 6
I go back and forth about how much I like this game. I always enjoy it, but sometimes I think it’s a 9 and other times I think it’s a 6. I got the Big Box at Origins 2014 without ever having played it, and that was a good choice (though I have yet to play more than 1 of the expansions).

This is Pimp Yo Palace. Basically, there are a bunch of different kinds of rooms (gardens, arcades, etc), and you stop three times to calculate points. On your turn, you can buy room and take money; if you use exact change to purchase a room, you can take another action. You get the bulk of your points from having the most of a type of room, but you also get points for the longest consecutive wall.

RATING: N/A
Tile laying.  There's a central market where you buy you and other players buy tiles, that gets randomly refilled as tiles get purchased.  Hand management, where your hand represents different forms of non-exchangeable currency to buy tiles, based on where they are in the market board.  Typical euro "scoring rounds" every so often.  Each player manages their own private tile area, but shares the central market.
