RATING: 8
Played this 4 times--once with a group of four who aborted when "Railroad Tycoon" arrived, and once with a friend.  The game lasted three hours, because I'd forgotten to institute the "Matt" rule, which creates a third "dummy" player who gets dealt six tiles each round and scores them at the end of the round as if he'd placed them legally.  In addition, you take one of each money card out of the deck to cut the overall length by a third.  Finally played a proper 2-player with my brother.  Worked out well.  I'll fold in the expansions in the future.

RATING: 4
I enjoyed this the first time I played it, but liked it less the second time. It's not a bad game, and the mechanics for scoring and earning bonus actions are excellent (as are the quality of the pieces and the novelty of the theme) -- it's just not interactive enough for me.

There's very little you can do to impact anyone else's game (apart from buying something you know they need, which is easier said than done), which isn't an automatic dealbreaker for me but does bug me in this case. On top of that, it's almost impossible to plan for your next turn -- what's available is almost certain to change before then. That's a bad combination.

I didn't see this coming out much except as an intro game for non-boardgamers, where I think it would serve quite nicely -- then I just never saw it come out at all, so I sold it.

RATING: 9
I really enjoyed this game-a lot of interesting elements going on here, from collecting coin cards to spend, and the fun of trying to sweep multiple pieces at once with 'exact change' before an opponent buys just the tile you wanted, to trying to stay ahead in various tile colors to earn the highest bonus, to placing the tiles correctly to maximize the length of your wall as well as to allow expansion with new bought tiles, while following all the rules about placement.  I liked it enough to go ahead and order the Big Box.  Also gave me a chance to go back and play the Alcazaba variant of the dice version (I played the dice game before this one).  This one's definitely a keeper, one of my highest rated games in my collection.

It’s a quiet, fun game with no conflict (you’re building a garden after all) that plays multiple people well. The theme gets buried a little bit but I love that it’s not just another “push the cubes around”.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
In [i]Alhambra[/i], each player builds his or her own, well, Alhambra.  To do so, one must purchase a series of tiles using the appropriate currency.  There are four different types of currency, which are obtained by drawing cards.  Each tile has a color, number and wall configuration.  

Scoring is achieved in two ways, as follows, and is done at three times during the game:

(1) Number of tiles in a particular color (if tied, the tiebreaker is the sum of the numbers on the tiles)

(2) Building a castle with a long continuous wall (you receive a point for each section of the wall)

Conflict in this game is for the most part indirect.  You are constantly comparing your Alhambra to that of your opponents to determine which color(s) you should be pursuing.  Also, you are trying to acquire these tiles in a way such that their walls fit into the configuration of your Alhambra.  At times, you will take certain cards/tiles to block your opponents, but doing so too often will hamper you from building your own Alhambra.

I suspect most will enjoy this as a family type game with 3-4 players.  The two-player variant is more cut throat.  It involves a dummy player who automatically receives tiles at certain intervals.  Also, players may purchase and strategically give tiles to the dummy (you may do this if, for instance, you are easily winning a category and you want your opponent to come in third).  I enjoy the two-player variant, but it definitely feels like a last minute add-on rather than the true vision of the game.

RATING: 7.5
I don't love this game, but there's a lot to like.  Not much direct interaction, but turns move fairly quickly.  I like that there's not much hidden information in terms of scoring, other than the randomness of the scoring rounds.  Working out the best tile placement is a fun puzzle and trying to plan ahead hoping the tile you want to buy survives until the next round adds some good suspense.  I've played with several of the expansions and while they're interesting, I have no problem playing the simple vanilla base game.  Solid euro and fairly easy to bring new players into, but I could see it being a bit dull to non-gamers.  Probably a safe bet if you like Carcassonne.

RATING: 9
A game of area control, resource management, and building. Use your numbered cards to bid on numbered tiles of different colors. If you pay "exact change," you get to take another turn of either collecting bidding cards or bidding on a tile again. If you overpay, you end your turn right there. If you cannot buy any tiles, you just collect more cards. The goal is to try to become first place in each color while using the tiles to build a palace. (Each tile has walls on them so you must configure your palace so that you can move freely from room to room). Takes about 15 minutes to explain. Three rounds of scoring with the first place getting cummulatively higher on each scoring round.  Simple enough to teach non-gamers but complex enough to hold the interest of gamers (well, most of them!). Fun, overall game that combines bidding, resource management, and a little bit of luck in what cards you draw.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
This is a fun "stock" collecting game.  Most people wouldn't categorize it as collecting stocks, but I think that is clearly what the main goal of the game.  When the first scoring round comes up you have to have the majority in a type of tile, on the second, you need to be first or second, and at the end of the game the top 3 are rewarded.  If you aren't scoring majority in some of the tile types you aren't going to win.  That is why I consider it a stock game.

The other aspect of this game that makes it interesting is that you have to be able to build your Alhambra (I think that was a city in Spain) in such a way that the tiles you buy can be added on.  If you buy a tile and can't add it, you don't get credit for it.  The tiles have sides with or without walls which makes things tricky at times.  You also get points for the longest wall you create.

This game gets worse as you add people.  With all 6 players the tiles you saw at the end of your turn will most likely be all different on your next turn.  Then it turns into more of a timing game, if the right tile comes up on my turn I'll do well, if not I lose.  I think 3 players is the best for this game.  The 2 player game has a good mechanic by adding a 3rd phantom player.  This player gets a pretty even number of tiles and jumps into his place for majorities in scoring rounds, but doesn't score walls.  He usually doesn't win, and probably should be in last place every time, but he does add a good twist that would otherwise ruin the 2 player game.  If you are playing with more players, especially 5 or 6, get the vizier's favor expansion.  That can help break up the timing factor, but I would still recommend playing with 3.

I gave this game an 8 because I enjoy playing it, with 3 players (sometimes 4), and I would never turn down a game if offered.  I enjoy building up my Alhambra as well as having to pay attention to the tiles others are collecting.

RATING: 6.5
2016-04-17

Moderate tile-laying game where players are building on individual player boards. There are score bonuses for collecting the most X type of buildings, longest wall, etc. The same bonuses are scored 3 times per game, so dominating one area ends up in steamrolling scores.

Odd mechanic is the ability to purchase extra cards if you pay with exact change. In the 6P game we played, the ability to "plan" to use exact change to get an extra action seemed very arbitrary, and very strong.

Decent enough for a tile-laying game, but might bug heavier gamers.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.75
Really want to get more plays of this. I understand its detractors that it is too much AP for what it is, too tactical, too random. Yet there is a certain beauty to your creation. Also the balance of raw purchasing power ("give me the big monies") versus the advantages of exact change ("give me multiple small monies and extra turns please") make for meaningful decisions even on turns you have seemingly nothing productive to do. Affordability, color, and wall configuration are all factors in your decisions, and each of those has subjective value depending on your current configuration and that of your opponents.

Does this building fit? Will it add to your wall score? Does it change the color majority? Will it give you a bonus turn? Is it worth taking into your reserve just to keep someone else from getting it? Will it still be there next turn? How close is the next scoring or the end of the game?

Chaos rises with the player count. Those who found the game too luck-based at 5 or 6 players should try it with 3 or 4. Commit to fast turns and I think this is a fun one.

Tipikus családi játék, kevés konflikttal, ám de néhány ötletes mechanizmussal, mint például a piac vagy maga az építkezés.

Belépő szintnek is elmegy, de kicsit azért annál komolyabb (nem kell megijedni, nem nagyon).

Ha meg már unalmas az alapjáték (újrajátszhatósága mondjuk kb. végtelen, az unalmas inkább arra vonatkozik, hogy hiányzik még belőle valami csavar, akár egy új mechanizmus), van hozzá rengeteg kiegészítő is, amik közül modulárisan akár egy-kettő beépítésével is lehet fokozni a kombinációs lehetőségeket. De vigyázat! Ha mindent beleteszünk, igazi agyégetős analízis-paralízis csata válhat belőle, ami nem mindenkinek a kedvenc időtöltése (euro fanok előnyben).

Vannak hasonlóságai a Carcassonne-nal: lapka lehelyezés, a Ticket to Ride-dal: pénzkártyák (amik ott ugye vonatok és nem épületeket lehet velük vásárolni, hanem útvonalat). Meg még valószínűleg több másik játékkal is.

RATING: 8
Alhambra ist eines dieser Spiele, die bei uns immer mal wieder auf den Tisch kommen. Die Regeln sind einfach erklärt und das Spielprinzip zeitlos. Es gibt 4 unterschiedliche, antike Währungen im Spiel. Davon versuchen die Spieler so passend wie möglich Teile für ihren Palast zu kaufen. Warum passend? Nun, dafür gibt es zwei Gründe: Erstens gibt es kein Wechselgeld und zweitens erhält man eine zusätzliche Aktion, wenn man passend bezahlt. Die unterschiedlichen Räume, die ein Palast so braucht, sind auf Plättchen dargestellt, die man dann in bester Carcasonne-Tradition an seinen Palast anbauen muss. Dabei gibt es einige Dinge zu beachten, z.B. muss jeder Teil des Palastes vom Startplättchen aus erreichbar sein. Während der drei Wertungen, bekommen die Spieler mit den meistens Gebäuden einer Art Siegpunkte. Alhambra ist eben ein zeitloser Klassiker und gehört in jede Sammlung!

RATING: 5
Alhambra is a bit too balanced. There is not enough differentiation among the upper tier majorities that what inevitably happens, it seems, is that someone gets first in one and the player who was in second place gets first in another where the first first player then has second, and so on. [Does that make any sense? No. Ok. Read it again?]

4 is probably the sweet spot for the game, to make enough competition for the second and third places in majority scoring, and to make it harder to hold on to a first place at that. But, with 4 [or more... *shudder*] the game is quite tactical and chaotic, falling prey to Through The Ages' "You can't know what will be available next turn" syndrome.

Actually managing the money and bonus actions is an interesting enough system [and reminds me a bit of Schacht's lovely mechanism in California], but ultimately the rest of the game just doesn't have enough ways for players to shake things up and the palace-building spatial puzzle is too limiting [with the wall] to your tile selection choices.

RATING: 9
I've played this a few times now and I really like it. It has a great simplicity to strategy ratio. The game is extremely easy to learn and teach yet there are enough interesting decisions to make every time your turn comes around that the game remains interesting throughout the game and on further replays as well. I like the simplicity of either buying tiles, rearranging your Alhambra/reserve board or simply taking money. 

Those 3 simple actions combined with the bonus turns you get when buying tiles for exact amounts causes the game to have a minimum of AP yet still has interesting decision making for a game in this light/midweight class. Definitely a 9 for me at the moment as we can play this with our 12 year old with no difficulty and the 2 player game works well enough that we can play that when it's just the two of us as well. I can see this game becoming a good "go-to" game to default to when we can't decide what else we want to play but have about an hour to fill in for boardgaming.

Still a solid 9 rating and one of my preferred light games currently.

RATING: 5
Alhambra is a simple game with some interesting decisions. Do you buy a tile before someone else does or do you take money to be able to buy it with an exact amount (and get an extra action)? Which colors do you buy to get or maintain a majority? How do you arrange them to keep your building options open? However, while skills are important, luck with the cards still seems to be the most decisive in the game.

RATING: 6.75
[u][BGCOLOR=#FFCC00]Review[/u][/bgcolor]: [url=https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/281531/alhambra-detailed-review]A detailed review (+ expansions)[/url]

2015-05-31: Note de 7.8 (de mai 2013) revue à la baisse - une seule partie (incomplète) jouée depuis ce temps. Aucune envie d'y jouer malgré l'acquisition de deux extansions. Trop de hasard et trop grand manque de contrôle peut-être?... La petite monnaie avantage les joueurs pouvant l'acquérir, afin d'ultérieurement pouvoir payer le prix exact et ainsi bénéficier d'actions supplémentaires.

Je suis tenté de donner une note inférieure à 6.75 mais l'existence de nombreuses extansions (non essayées) pallient possiblement aux faiblesses du jeu de base.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
Tile placement meets set collection, it's a game about efficiency. There's a small amount of interaction as you have to constantly look at your opponent's tableau to determine what colored tile to take. There's a lot of luck though, particularly when new tiles are turned up.  

The four-color currency and getting extra turn when you purchase a building in exact are what annoys me most as these rules feel very gamey without making it more strategic (in fact probably more random). The only good thing about it is it's easy, but even then it actually takes quite a bit of time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Alhambra looks appealing, and touts much acclaim, but suffers from horrendous design flaws. Alhambra is the type of game you have to learn through experience and punishment; Alhambra doesn't know how to protect players from themselves, and entire game sessions become lop-sided lost causes if any player realizes too late that a rule was forgotten or misunderstood. Games should not require luck just to have a level playing field, and Alhambra's exclusive use of random drawing is an extreme detriment. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My love for this game has cooled a bit but it is still a good game. There is a lot of luck in the tile and money draws which can be both fun and frustrating at times. I do love seeing the completed Alhambras at the end. A good game for newcomers to the hobby and lighter family play. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
[--- What I like about it ---]
The game mechanics are extremely simple.  The number of things to learn are few but the choices to be made have an impact on the game.  A blend of luck and skill.  And there is a subtle hint of ruthlessness towards beating out your opponents.

[--- What I don't like about it ---]
This game can be frustrating with more than four players.  Beyond that, if a card comes up that you want, it's almost guaranteed to be gone by your turn, making this feel like more luck than choices.

[--- Other comments ---]
This game has an interesting 2-player variant where you have a pretend 3rd player.

RATING: 6.4
Straightforward game in which players are simultaneously trying to draft both money to buy tiles and the tiles that they will use to score points. The exact change mechanism, which gives players an extra action each time they pay exactly in the required currency, is a great rule and often the differentiator between winning and losing. There's something self-balancing here between grabbing too much money and overpaying for too many tiles that I find satisfying. The spatial puzzle of designing your palace puts this one above its card game predecessor.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

I really like the building mechanics - this adds a welcome new dimension to the game. My rating reflects the disparity when played by differing numbers of players: 2 Players - 6.5, 3-4 Players - 8, 5 players - 5, 6 Players - 4. Overall a 7. ***UPDATE*** In a recent 6-player game, we used the add-on rule of being able to buy a tile out of turn for exact money. It helped a bit, but I still dislike this game with any more than 4 players.

RATING: 2
Wow, is this game ever random!  Do you have players who's minds wander during a game, or who tend to chat and pay no attention whatsoever to what's going on until it's their turn?  Well that might be a negative in most games, but that's status quo in this one!

There is nothing you can do to affect this game until it rolls around to your turn, so you might as well have a side game going on to occupy your time while the other players are engaging themselves with the business of stealing your opportunities.  And the card drafting just makes matters worse, allowing those who can pay exact amounts (even if they have less cash than you) to get extra plays, thereby gaining extra cards.  This often has the net effect of them MAKING A PROFIT on their purchase while you are forced to overpay.  Yeah, that's fair.  What a random piece of crap.  My rating is plummeting even as I type this.

No wonder non-gamers seem to take to this one so well.  It's a game that they have as much of a chance of winning as veteran gamers.  Heck, a stinkin' trained monkey with a lobotomy could play this as well as anyone else!

RATING: 7
This is a pretty quick-to-play game with rules that are not very tough to learn.  You have different monetary values that allow you to buy different buildings at different times for your city.  The two ways to score are by counting the biggest continuous wall surrounding your city and the amount of buildings you own in each color compared to your opponents.  You score 4 times per game.

The fact that this is such an easy/quick game to learn/play, and gives players enough choices to feel like they are the ones winning, not just by luck, is what will keep this game in my collection for a long time coming.

RATING: 4.5

RATING: 7
Alhambra is one of those games that I feel is a 7, a strong 7, but my friends wonder why I never offer to play it.

Well the reason for that is simply because I like playing other themed games.  Does this game have 'theme'?  Eh.  It feels like you're building an alhambra, yes!  But do I want to build an alhambra?  Not often, I usually rather build an army, a galactic empire, fly through space, trade resources, and whatever else.

Want to play a really fun euro?  Get this game!  It's a very strong euro game that has tons of simple mechanics to make you coming back for more.  The way to get money, expand your profits, and develop a building offers different ways to generate the most points to win.

The game offers a 2 player variant that actually doesn't just make me feel like I'm just removing resources.  Dirk actually feels like he's playing the game and blocking some plays.

It plays relatively fast and is extremely easy to learn.

One thing I did notice however is that often the leader will blow everyone one out of the water as far as taking a lead at the end.  It's not necessarily bad since that huge point lead doesn't happen till final scoring, but still, people always feel like they messed up some where.

I stand by this game as a great family game and a phenomenal euro.  I just am not into the theme usually, but I always enjoy playing it.

[so why are other games lower score than this one?  Because this game is high value outside 'theme' games.  I hold theme based games on much higher pedastool than family games that don't push theme].
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I enjoy this game -- a good balance of luck and efficient decision-making, it's easy to teach new gamers, and experienced players can play rather quickly.  Luck is a factor in this game, so it is understandable that not every player will enjoy it.  A player with a "lucky streak" can pull into the lead, but this is also true of games like Settlers and Carcassone.  

Alhambra does have player interaction, but it's very indirect.  This is not a solitaire game of "build a nice palace," after all; your goal is to score more points than the other players by edging out leads in the various types of buildings and building chains of walls.  Anyone who ignores the other players is unlikely to do well.  Fun if you're willing to accept a bit of randomness.  The expansions, especially the Worker Huts in the first expansion, add a lot more options (and more strategic choices) if you want a slightly heavier game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Alhambra isn't a particularly innovative game - players bid for tiles so that they can build a complex of buildings that holds the biggest amount of each type of bluidings and as many walls as possible. There are five money cards and four building tiles on display, each building being sold by its amount of points in a different currency); a player can in their turn take a money card into their hand, buy a tile with money from their hand to place it on Alhambra or reserve, or alter the layout of the Alambra. All in the best German style.

What is memorable about Alhambra, though, is its huge variety: the different combinations of buildings and currencies bring a different challenge each game, and even though players can still benefit from a good draw good timing is required to carry out the right actions at the right time. The level of interaction is reduced to the classical "snatch them before the others do" but the play still feels fresh and dynamic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
Delusione per un vincitore dello Spiel des Jahres tra l'altro apprezzato da molti miei amici. In sintesi ho trovato il gioco noioso, astratto, ripetitivo e completamente governato dalla fortuna. RATING: 6
A set of interesting elements which don't quite tie together well enough. There needs to be more building restriction and better money distribution for this to really work. But, on the plus side, there are some good quality pieces and art, and a game pitched perfectly to appeal to an array of players. The base game's one-dimensionality is improved by a plethora of add-as-you-like expansions, often (but not always) resulting in something a little more strategic. 

Two-player variants often feel a bit bolted-on, but this one works just fine and best of all is the entirely natural interplay between having a long-term strategy and tactical backstabbing when playing with two.

RATING: 8
[b]Alhambra[/b] was traded away with Thebes for El Grande Decennial Edition 10/28/14.
Received in a trade (3/11/14).

[COLOR=#FF0000]A year later... thoughts and rating (10):[/COLOR]

[i]This was a game my wife and I enjoyed, but our kids never got into it. The much prefer the tile laying found in Carcassonne or the route building in Ticket to Ride (both are different games, but fill a similar niche in our collection). I ended up trading this away because my wife and I did not enjoy the 2 player variant. In the end I am sad to see this go, but I know it would just sit on our shelves.[/i]

[COLOR=#FF0000]Initial thoughts and rating (9):[/COLOR]

[i]- Tile laying/ building your city, which is always a hit in my house.
- Having to figure out the layout of your alhambra in order to extend the outer walls.
- Simplicity of choices: buy tiles, take money and add/place tiles from your reserve.
- $ management: you need to buy tiles with specific colored money and if you pay exact change you get another turn.
- Uncertain scoring rounds which adds some tension to when you want to lay tiles versus stockpile cash.
- The anniversary edition has beautiful components with a really nice board. It is too bad this is not the standard edition that Queen puts out.[/i]

RATING: N/A
A nice medium weight, weeknight game. This is a simple game with a great money collecting mechanic and fun puzzle mechanic for tile laying. The game is excellent for 2-players and probably a lot more competitive with more. 

You start the game with cards totaling 20pts or more (which is great, because players starts with a different number of cards due to the coin totals on their cards). You may draw more money cards or buy Alhambra tiles. If you can exactly match (in money) the cost of the tile, you may buy something else or take money cards. Once you get your tile(s) place them on your Alhambra (your own personal city that you are making) or on your board. Be careful to make a nice long wall around your city for extra points.

Otherwise, I would give this one a 4 or a 5.

RATING: 7
心得:
越玩越覺得是挺吃運氣的遊戲
雖然判斷還是挺重要的
規則:
*將一個玩家標記放在自己的獅子泉起始板塊，另一個放在分數0。
*將貨幣卡洗勻後，每位玩家翻卡直到數字總合>=20為止，並成為該玩家手牌。
*翻開4張貨幣於遊戲版圖旁，將剩餘的貨幣分為5堆，將第一張計分卡塞入第二堆後洗勻，第二張則塞入第四堆後洗勻，依照順序將貨幣卡由上往下堆成一疊， 遊戲由手牌張數最少的玩家成為起始玩家。
行動三選一
1.拿取貨幣
玩家從場上攤開的挑選1張，或是拿取任意張數但總和最高為5的貨幣卡。
2.購買建築
玩家付出該建築上標示數字的貨幣卡，且貨幣要對應該格，如果金額剛好，可或得一次額外行動，購買到的建築物待回合結束一起進行建設，不建設的板塊可放至自己的玩家板塊上。
阿爾罕布拉宮建設規則
*所有建築物的方向都必須和獅子泉起始板塊同一方向
*每個連接的建築，其邊線都必須互相符合，即城牆連接城牆，或空曠接空曠。
*至少有一邊與目前已蓋好的板塊相連，不得角對角相連。
*每個建築物都必須遵守從起始板塊「步行可達」的規則，須穿過圍牆或是根本無法到達則不行。
*不得在建設後產生封閉的空洞。
3.改變建設
當要改變阿爾罕布拉宮的建設時，由以下三個方式挑選一項進行。
a.從玩家板塊上的建築挑選一個建設放入阿爾罕布拉宮內。
b.從玩家的阿爾罕布拉宮內挑選一個建築放至玩家板塊上。
c.將玩家板塊上的一個建築與阿爾罕布拉宮內的一個建築交換。
*翻開計分卡，則將計分牌放到一旁；補回4張翻開的貨幣卡後，隨即計算分數，最長圍牆一個一分，顏色建築平手，分數平分，如計算到第二名則把一二分數加總除二，無條件捨去
*當某位玩家的回合結束時，無法將場上的建築板塊補至4張時，遊戲結束，根據現金發剩下版塊(平手都沒有)，並最後記分

RATING: 7.7
Nice fast paced game. Easy to learn. Good filler, good game for six players. 

Tried a six player game with five exapansions and the promo = 21 modules. Only the setup took 90 mins. Since all the expansions was new for all of us it took quite some time to play. We also realized with that many modules, you had to concentrate on a few of them, both of strategic reasons and because you couldn't keep track of everything. It was still fun though. 

Since then I have played a four player base game only game, and it was as fun. The most important thing in the beginning is to get a lot of cards so you can do at least two buys when you but, preferably two even money buys so you also get to pick money. Never buy only one tile unless it's very important for your majority and/or close to scoring. Don't underestimate blue and red tiles, since they are fewer you can easily get a secure majority and score them all three times.

RATING: 7.5
My SO's favorite game, she usually wins. It is a fun game that has some depth. I'd say a step further than TTR.

(01/18) Plays recorded here don't cover all of the times I've played it, it was one of the first games I got, so it got played a lot, at least 8 times more than what it says here.

When picking up a game, I feel ticket to ride is easier to explain, so with people not familiar with boargames maybe I'd go with it, as I said before, Alhambra feels like TTR with a bit more to it, the satisfaction of the tile laying makes it a favorite with people who have already played some boardgames and are looking to pump up. Really fun to get played with friends who already know it. There's a lot of luck on the tiles that get on the market and the money you get from the deck, but that adds up to the notion of advancing and taking chances with the things that are available.

I think I'd never get rid of it. Plus my girlfriend would kill me. I wish there was a way to play 2p without having to have that dummy player.

RATING: 6
Update:  Alhambra is good, but not good enough compared to other games out there.  Don't get me wrong, if all you had was Alhambra, you'd have a great time turning to it again and again...  however, the game is very random and is best played with 3 or 4, or else you lose any sense of control.  It's a good game for people who have played a few rounds of Carcassonne and Settlers of Catan, and would like to see how they may work  if they were combined together.  Sorta.  Good game, but not as good as some of the others I own. :D

When do I play this?:
I play Alhambra with my friends who are new to eurogames but yearn for something deeper.  This is usually after they've played Carcassonne and find it too basic.

RATING: 8
I like to work on my own Alhambra without interference from the other players; thus, this is the type of "no conflict" game that I enjoy. Still, you need to be aware of the tile distribution and the length of your opponents' wall; otherwise, you end the game with a great-looking Alhambra that's not worth the winning total. And don't be afraid to spend more on tiles than they're worth. I've lost a game or two because I was trying to obtain exact change for available tiles instead of buying critical tiles for more coins than they were worth. I'm talking about tiles that make you the majority holder or tiles that join two long walls together.

RATING: 6
After a revisit to Alhambra I can still see the appeal of the gameplay: there is almost constant tension as there is often a race to amass money for the desired tile, which is also fuelled by the desire to hold off overpaying for it to instead draw currencies to pay exact for the powerful and gratifying extra turn(s).

But the adrenalin doesn't stop there with the push your luck element as there is the exciting scoring cards somewhere in the drawpile. One feature here at Alhambra from its predecessor Stimmt So is that a player can take as many currency cards upto the value of 5 or less so can speed up the appearance of the scoring card if it is to their advantage.

Then there is the climax at game end when only 1-3 tiles are left to draft and these are purchased in a reveal (my favourite game feature) by the player holding the most in that currency. Like Ticket to Ride, Alhambra is very good gateway game, filled with anxiety and table-thumping frustration as someone else does what you wanted to do.

So thankfully there are moments of relief when the scoring takes place, and this is the first of some niggles I have with the design. My pet peeve of majority scoring is here and whereas in Stimmt So the 'shares' were clumped together to make comparisons easier on the eye, in Alhambra's change to a tile laying subgame (possibly due to the success of Carcassonne), the colours of the player's share holdings are scattered.So really not an improvement over Stimmt So as time spent scoring has partially increased as well as thinking where to best put the tile.

And tiles are probably the biggest complaint for me: to make any skilful decision really requires knowledge of the tile manifest, and here it is too detailed for my taste. I don't think the colour quantity on the player boards are enough, I like to know have I wasted my time putting a wall here, will there be another one to put next to it, and more importantly what will be the colour and price of the tile? I like that the wall(s) can make it easier to determine if it is desirable or not for an opponent to fit into his grounds, and they are another source of vps, but my threshold for tile-drawing assesments is probably at the Zooloretto level.

I've also noticed that the game runs on two chaotic features, the tile draw and the currency deck, but as these are both drafted and so long as the game is kept at 3 players I don't mind it so much (though I've noticed that the expansions seem to address this level of chaos; if it starts to bother me too much, there is always Palazzo to fall back on). So after the revisit, I'm happy to play occasionally but I much prefer O Zoo le Mio's swift majority scoring and gameplay (though I may be tempted with the new version which joins the fragemented boards into a colourful overhead shot of Alhambra with everything centralised and more importantly the scoring track on the outside, rather than off to one side).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
-

This is an enjoyable game with a high replayability factor. The theme is building the city of Alhambra (Spain) by buying/building tiles that represent different types of buildings and paying for them by cards that represent four different types of currencies. It is on the light/medium strategy side and is very accessible to non-gamers as well.

The rule about taking another turn when you buy a tile by paying for it with the exact amount of money, which is a fundamental component of the game, gives the game an inherent element of luck. Virtually all winning strategies revolve around and rely on utilizing this rule, so the game can not rid itself of a prominent luck factor.
Despite this, I think it is a great game and fun and entertaining and the luck factor is not overwhelming and good play will pay off. I enjoy this game every time I play it.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
In Alhambra each player is trying to build the awesomest Alhambra.  I hated the game after my first play.  I've since played it a couple more times.  It's random enough to make the game feel pointless at times.  The puzzle aspect is fun.  There's a bit of player interaction in trying to grab a tile before your opponent does.  Randomness plays heavily in being able to do so.

On each player's turn there are four different tiles available for purchase and four currency cards face up and available to draft from.  Cards of various colors and denominations represent the currency in the game.  The tiles represent various buildings you can arrange in your Alhambra.  Some tiles have walls on some of their edges.  Tiles have to be placed such that the walls line up properly.  This gives the game its puzzle feel.

On a turn a player can draft a card or buy a tile.  Tiles can only be bought with a specific kind of currency.  If you have a bunch of yellow money and your ideal tile must be paid for in blue money you are out of luck.  You don't get change for your purchases, but if you pay the exact price for a tile that action doesn't count as your action for the turn and you can keep playing.  Tiles and cards that are scooped up are replaced by random draws.  So if you've been saving up yellow money and someone buys the tile you've been eying you better hope its replacement is useful to you.

Players score points three times during the game for majorities in the various types of buildings and for have long contiguous walls surrounding their Alhambra.  Arranging the Alhambra is the funnest part of the game.  Hoping the tile draw favors you is the worst part.  If you are playing a four player game it is possible that three of the four tiles that are available at the end of your turn will be bought up.  This rapid fluctuation of the game state can suck enjoyment out of the game.  

Players can track the cards others are drawing and the buildings they are aiming for to help make informed decisions.  This adds some push-your-luck feel and player interaction to the game.  One game I played had very few blue money cards coming up so when it was my turn I would pick up what few blue cards became available.  When blue cards started to come out more plentifully I started snatching up the blue tiles as I desired.  There are ways to game the randomness and that helps the game rise to mediocrity.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
This game was fun and a bit of a challenge.  You take turns buying addition(s) or picking up money.  You may purchase an addition(s)and put it aside, however taking the building back from your pool counts as your turn.  Use this move judiciously.  Buildings in the storage pool at the end do not count.  You receive points for having the most of a color(s) and for having the longest contiguous wall.

RATING: 9.988
I have always referred to this game as the next step after TTR. I find the set collecting is almost identical when it comes to collection cards to spend on the tiles but it also allows you to track what people are choosing and the number value to incorporate that info into choosing when best to strike or wait one more turn.

There is also a little bit of route building by trying to have a lengthy wall surrounding your Alhambra. This proves to be challenging because of the rules for placing tiles along with the timing of when you are able to purchase said tiles.

Also, I love the second Set Collection aspect of the game which is the main way of scoring. Obviously you are trying to have more of certain colour tiles than your opponents and this becomes challenging due to your limited purchasing power based on only being able to buy certain tiles with currency of a specific colour.

For such a simple game it offers many great strategic choices to make and a very nice visual at the end of the game which combines to make one of my favourite gaming experiences.

RATING: 6.5
Enjoyable game - it suffers, though, from the turn-by-turn luck of what gets replaced in the money cards and tiles. I like individualized luck, but not in this kind of planning/building game. Vegas Showdown took this mechanic from Alhambra and added to it, while at the same time making the luck component fair to everyone, not just to the player that gets a good tile and/or card come up. 

Played multiple times, and yep - the randomness of tiles, cash, and turn order basically makes a mockery of planning and control of your Alhambra placements. Inferior game. Revising rating down from 8 to 6.5 - while there is strategy in comparing your colors to other leaders, it is not enjoyable strategy to me.
It is unenjoyable with 6 players, and wouldn't be good with 5.

RATING: 9.9
Ottimo titolo, mantiene sempre una buona dose di rigiocabilità, è semplice da insegnare anche ai "non-gamers" (alias "Babbani") grazie ad una meccanica di gioco assai semplice e divertente. Comunque c'è molta tattica nascosta dietro alla apparente semplicità del gioco, strategico da 2 a 4 giocatori, mentre in 5 o in 6 tende ad essere condizionato dalla fortuna. Bisogna sempre ponderare le proprie scelte e cercare di non sperperare quantità abnormi di denaro per costruzioni con troppe mura che poi non possano esser piazzate e così occorre tenere sott'occhio tutte le tessere che escono, razionalizzare i soldi, "affondare" con gli acquisti al momento giusto (non troppo presto), tenere d'occhio le mura... Tanti aspetti, ma tutti gestibili. La tensione rimane alta fino alla fine! Con giocatori esperti si finisce sempre con punteggi molto vicini. Ha dei materiali buoni da un punto di vista qualitativo e dell'impatto grafico… e poi è una gioia per gli occhi veder crescere "sapientemente" la propria Alhambra! Spiel des Jahres... 2003.

RATING: 3
i enjoyed playing this, but it the game definitely suffers from lack of control. there are some tactical decisions to be made, but you mainly just have to hope to get lucky. like a lot of card drafting games, what is available for you to draft determines the usefulness of your turn.  since alahambra is less forgiving than say, ticket to ride, the negative aspects of this mechanic are highly amplified.

also, the extra actions for buying buildings for the exact amount seems like a questionable design choice.  this system just rewards people who are lucky enough to collect money useful to them, which just serves to further punish those players who are less lucky.

RATING: 7
[b]RO[/b]: [i]01/24/2016[/i]

Alhambra is one of the older games in my collection. It is a tile laying game, with aspects of hand management and it is a fine example of a game that player great with two and gradually becomes a chaotic mess the more players you add from there. But that kind of makes it sound like I don't like it, and I do. Trying to snag certain tiles before other people do and bemoaning the lack of (insert color here) currency because [i]that[/i] is the currency you [i]need[/i] to purchase that juicy garden tile to take the lead in that category from Bob who is only beating you by five points and if you take it you'll win the game, but wait [i]that[/i] tile will allow you to connect your two long pieces of wall making them contiguous and getting you [i]even more[/i] points... *deep breath*... that is Alhambra.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

6/3/10 - As of this writing I have played it 3 times without any expansions.  I have enjoyed myself each time I have played and look forward to playing again.  This would be a good game to try on folks who aren't dedicated board gamers.  The rules are relatively simple and the playing time seems about right- not too long or too short.

I worry about the game becoming a bit repetitive after many plays, but I suppose that may be why there are so many expansions - to spice things up.

RATING: 8.26
Great family game.  Great 2P game ("Dirk" as a 3rd player and less chaos than with more players).  You buy tiles (rather than just blinding drawing them as in Carc).  You lay tiles in your own city, rather than a common city like Carcassonne.  It also has a set collection element since the largest set of tiles of that color score victory points.  The layout of your Alhambra is also important as the length of your exterior wall, also scores victory points.  It's pretty quick and a lot of fun.  Recommended.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Review from 28th April 2015 at LoB meet at Red Herring.

A potentially good alternative to Ticket to Ride with a set collection and tile laying mechanic that rewards efficiency and planning, with an element of push your luck.

The concept of building your gardens and receiving points based upon having the most of a particular structure within 5 categories is a good one - and serves as an excellent gateway game.

Where the game falls short is in the execution of its theme (Ticket to Ride is so much stronger), especially the poor quality and small size of the tiles. With better quality components and much better artwork, the theme would be so much stronger and enticing for new players to the hobby.

There is an enjoyable family game here - just let down by component quality and artwork.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Likes
I really enjoy set collection games and Alhambra is great in this area. It is supported by fun modular expansions that let you make the game as simple or complex as you like. Finally, building your town is like putting together a puzzle and being able to do so efficiently without the use of your reserve is a satisfying mental exercise.

Dislikes
Sometimes the randomness of the tiles and your draw of cards converge with the chaos of being a multiplayer game to doom you no matter what you do. Some of the expansions mitigate this a bit but every once in awhile you just have a plain unlucky game.

RATING: 6
A tense, solitaire-like game with simple rules.  I know there is a population out there that enjoys such games, but the lack of interaction keeps me from truly enjoying the game.  Though there's competition between players, 99% of your time is looking at your mat and nobody else's.  Still, it's a pretty good game, revolving around the mechanic "get 1st, 2nd, 3rd place in as many competitions as possible".  However, I feel no emotional attachment to this game--it's hard to get passionate about this game which, though a solid mechanic, has very little interaction and whose ruleset can be summed up as "a game about making exact change".  It's like doing interesting math puzzles--kind of fun, but not something you'd do with a group of people (or at least, I wouldn't).

RATING: 6
15-02-2015. Rated after 2-3 plays. In Alhambra you build buildings from a central offer. 

You can buy a building tile, or get money cards (multiples as long as their sum is below or equal to 5) in multiple colors, or switch a previously built tile towards your personal supply, or build a tile from your personal supply. The twist is that if you can match the cost of the card exactly (money always must be the required color) thus if you do not overpay you get an additional action.

I did like Alhambra, but with 5 it ran a little long. I can see myself playing this more with 3 or 4.

RATING: N/A
Felt like there was too much to think about each turn which made the game more stressful and frustrating than fun and enjoyable. 

Not only do you have to think about which tile you can afford with the proper currency, you simultaneously have to think about how it will fit in your Alhambra and how the tile compares with those of your opponents for scoring—and that’s all before even playing a hand.

After a while the game stopped being about purchasing tiles and became just finding ways to arrange the tiles and trying to place the tiles from your reserve. 

Player interaction felt pretty minimal.

RATING: 7
I enjoy this game, although I believe the move from the city to the holding area, or from the holding area to the city is too costly.  I think a player should be able to rearrange all tiles for a move, instead of just one.  But in any case, this game is fun and i enjoy playing it.  It requires analyzing what your opponents are going for, so you don't get caught up in a war for specific tiles. Also, luck is involved - players can't control what tiles will have to be bought with which currency and when.  Sometimes you just have to be in the right spot at the right time with this game.  And I suggest only buying tiles if you have exactly enough money - this allows double turns. :)

RATING: 6
A nice, rightly  regarded family game...

Everybody is collecting different currencies to purchase parts for the Alhambra (a castle/city in Spain). On your turn you may pick one currency card (money), buy a tile and lay it to your already existing Alhambra or take a turn rearranging a tile. If you can pay the costs exactly you get an extra action. There are 3 scoring rounds during which you compare the number of building of each type. The player with the most buildings in each category gets the most points according to a chart and extra points for walls.

This game is easy to teach (maybe 5 min.) and fast with quick turns and low downtimes between players. Seeing your own little Alhambra growing in front of you is very attractive and placement is meaningful due to these annoying walls around some tiles edges... This game has a similar charm like Carcasson - a good entry level...

RATING: 8
Very pleased with this game. A vast improvement over Stimmt So. The walls add variation to the points scoring and are a wonderful extra consideration / headache for city planning. Suddenly tiles of the same colour are more attractive to buy than others due to how they fit the physical puzzle. Players find competition for a tile colour coming from unexpected corners due to the available wall shape. The pace of the game is just right and at the end of the day it's fun. Worth getting a copy for my shelves because it'll be taken down and played often. For me I see an element of Ra in the game that appeals - the pushing your luck / playing chicken waiting game. I'm torn between picking up good sets of money cards so I can bid exact amounts and get on a roll, or picking up a tile that I've just got to have. Plays well with four or less.

RATING: 6
There is nothing very impressive here. The optimal moves are rarely hidden and a simple algorithm yields a honest result:

Can you buy something with the exact amount of money? Yes -> do it; No -> take money.

Add a pinch of: Is a scoring about to take place? Yes -> take that building that gives you the majority; No -> don't bother.

Ok, maybe I am over-simplifying everything, but you get the idea.

The game is enjoyable with 3 players (even the 2-player variant is not too bad) but it gets worse as players are added, as everything becomes way too chaotic... and too long. I remember a 6-player game that nearly made me drop gaming nights altogether...

RATING: 7
Provisional rating.

Finally played this as a three player game. I've owned it for a long time, but the two-player rules seemed atrocious (ugh, imaginary third player, phtbth), and it never got to the table.

I thought it had some interesting mechanisms. However, it ran on a little longer than it should. The scoring is somewhat cumbersome. You spend a lot of time figuring out which color building you need more and doing the math, or just say to hell with the math because it all works out to 3-4 point gains no matter what you do unless you're playing with folks who don't grasp the scoring.

I do like how the designer approached money management. Each turn you have four buildings available to purchase, and each of the four sits in a currency slot. You must use the correct currency to buy that building. There are also four money cards of varying currencies. You do not get change if you overpay, and if you pay exact you get another turn. Nice. If you use your turn to take from the money cards tableau, you can take one card with any value, or any two cards totaling five or less. Nice. You set up the game with each player drawing money cards until they've got a value of 18 or greater. The player with the fewest cards goes first. If there's a tie, the player with the lowest value goes first. Nice again.

I'd like to play this with four, to see if that improves or worsens my opinion. It's easy enough to learn.

RATING: 7.5
Alhambra -- Played four- and five-player.  This has often been compared with Palazzo.  I found the two games markedly different from one another. While the two games share some elements which invite comparison, each game as a whole differs so much from the other that broad comparisons are simply inappropriate.  So (just to be inappropriate), I thought Alhambra was more difficult, in terms of both rules complexity and strategy. That difficulty makes good play commensurately more satisfying. Palazzo, on the other hand,  was more approachable and faster. Happily, we own both.

I enjoy tile-laying games, and the walls on the tiles in Alhambra make the tiles and their placement an integral part of the game. A pretty deep game for one so fun -- Of course, I find constructive games engaging.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1.5
after a year or two of nonplaying I confirm initial observation: 
[u]It's a tile laying set collecting MPS[/u]. 
And that's more or less it. Each player has it's own tableau/board, doing one's own stuff, competition happens via comparison of sizes of sets one collects. 

The good parts: for all the beige and the pastels, the tiles actually look neat and make this game a nice objet on top of a table. Also 2 player option with a dummy player Dirk actually works and adds some welcome tension. 

The bad parts. Well. All mentioned in first paragraph. Also when you think about it the 4 currencies make no sense (apart being in designer's previous game, which served as a basis for this one). 

Verdict: silent, harmless 2 player game. With more people I have no need for silence, and when I do, RFTG or Thunderstone (with theme) will be my MPS games of choice.

RATING: 6
I enjoyed this the first time I played. After that, I haven't been able to find any interesting decisions to make.

It has some nice parts: nice tiles, good use of colors and patterns, and some choice between furthering your wall or leaving open spaces. But ultimately it comes down to lucky tile draws.

While in theory I can see that you may not want to buy an item for exact change, in practice it doesn't seem like it will ever happen; you'll but it if only to mess up someone else's plans.

RATING: 5
[7 plays] Have played with 5, 4, and 2 players with the dummy player. 

Luck of the tile selection, luck of how the walls are configured on the tiles, and luck of the money available - ALL play a major role in this game. The extra action for exact change is a big advantage, so getting lucky here can lead to compounding your luckiness (i.e. I get a tile for exact change, I get another tile for exact change, and then I pick up more money to further increase my odds of having exact change the next turn. WoooHoo!) 

Alhambra is a tactical contest with 2 players, but it isn't a deep thinker where you might feel bad if you do poorly. With 4 or 5 it is a social game without much need to track events or strategize between turns, because stuff changes too much before it gets around to you again.

Good points for some people may include some interesting mechanics, quick turns, majority scoring, limited screwage, and quality components. But for me, it's just 95% a tactical contest strongly dictated by random events.

I'll flat out admit that I dislike the game, and it tends to leave me cold. In my most recent game I didn't play smartly either, so I'll take some of the blame and hope I didn't spoil anyone else's experience with negativity. Other people enjoy the game, and for the most part that baffles me, but I don't mean to lessen their enjoyment. I'll almost always gladly play games my friends and loved-ones enjoy more than me, but perhaps I should just stay away from this one so that I don't ruin it for other people. Weird, I guess this is a rare game that sparks such a negative reaction from me.

Most recent play 6-16-06 with Michael, Alex, Corey, and Garrett.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Alhambra is a great social game. In the game, you build your own Alhambra (palace) by purchasing pavilions, towers, gardens, etc. and adding them onto your sprawling complex. These components are purchased with four different types of currency, which you collect from a pool of four available cards. The palace-components are drawn from a bag and randomly placed on a little placard where each component aligns with a different kind of currency. On any given turn, you may take a currency card, OR purchase a component, OR remodel your palace. However, if you manage to purchase a palace component with precisely the correct amount of currency, you may take another action. The game has three scoring rounds, during which players with the most of any particular kind of palace component receive points. Alhambra restricts a players choices enough so that the game doesn't become a brain burner - after all, there are few available choices on a player's turn, and one or two usually stand out as optimal. Despite this restriction, Alhambra manages to be tactical and strategic at the same time. Every turn, you must make the best choice given your options and your ability to forecast the next few moves - but you also need to look ahead to the later scoring rounds and attempt to establish dominance in a few different areas (gardens, towers, manors, or etc. etc.). It is too bad that there is usually such an obvious right choice on a player's turn, as I think the game would be enriched by some heckling and cajoling ("You should *really* take that manor. What a steal, and look, it will give you such and such benefits.") - which if successful, would then provide the cajoler with preferred options. But Alhmabra doesn't lend itself to this kind of interaction. There is definitely a lot more control in a two player game. Adding players decreases the amount of control a player has, and decreases opportunities for skilfull play. I enjoy playing this, but it doesn't compel me as some other games do.

RATING: 7
[2010-09-06]
Lapkalerakós, egyszerű szabályokkal rendelkező igazi családi játék. Egyértelműen hárman a legjobb, 2-en talán túl egyértelmű, hogy mit kell tenni, többen pedig a játékidő nyúlhat meg és teljesen más piac alakul ki, mire újra sorra kerül egy-egy játékos. Sokak kedvence, nem véletlenül. A töménytelen kiegészítő csak színesíti az amúgy sem unalmas játékmenetet. De valamiért minden jósága ellenére sem fogott meg.

[2011-06-06]
Ahogy már korábban is írtam nem fogott meg a játék, de igazából nem utasítok vissza egy partit sem vele, mert egy jó játékról van szó. A kiegészítők hatalmas számú kombinálási lehetősége pedig tényleg sokat jelent, bár szerintem az alapjáték önmagában is jó.
1-es, 2-es és 4-es kiegészítő minden elemével sikerült játszanom. Számomra magasan a 2-es kiegészítő viszi a pálmát, abban mind a 4 részkiegészítő tetszett. Az 1-es és 4-es közül talán árnyalatnyival a 4-es tetszett jobban, aki egy kis csetepatéra vágyik egyértelműen azt válassza, aki viszont kis titkosságra annak az 1-est ajánlom.

[2011-10-16]
Sikerült a 3-as kiegészítő összes elemét is megismernem. Ezek után pedig már egy meghatározható rangsort tudok felállítani az első 4 kieg tekintetében. A sorrendem 2-4-3-1. A BGG-n adott pontszámban a 3-as és 1-es között nem tettem különbséget, de érdekes módon az 1-es sikerült talán a legrosszabbra. A 2-es pedig egyértelműen a legjobb.
Nagyon sok kiegészítővel játszva szerintem sokat romlik a játékélmény. Én 2-3 kiegészítő együttes használatát javaslom.

RATING: 8
Alhambra was one of my early introductions to European or German-style board games. It's still one of my favorites and probably one of my top five to play with three players. I enjoy the money drafting, the spatial aspect of building the city tile by tile, and the satisfying combos you can pull off by doing both of those things efficiently. Scoring is always pretty tight and everyone I've played this with has a had a good time. I do have the deluxe version with the wooden fountains and it's disappointing that they aren't included in every version since it really helps with both the theme and the game play. If you're wanting a strong, beginner-level, family board game, I can't recommend this one enough.

RATING: 3
Ok, first of all, this isn't given a three because it is a bad game, rather it just doesn't appeal to my sensibilities.  This game frustrates me because it really is only working percentiles; guessing which number combinations will get you ahead.  The only way to be effective in this game is paying exact change and getting the extra move.  If you do this then you can get your building and more money.  If you can't do this you can only get a building or money, leaving you farther and farther behind.  Can be frustrating watching others do this when you can't (or being the only one able to do this while others are frustrated).  Not really heavy on fun factor.  Worst of all, it is absolutely unforgiving. If you make a mistake it can take three turns to correct, leaving you miserable.  In addition to this there is tons of downtime and no player interactivity.  Blech.

RATING: 8.5

Seeing the tile you need get picked up by someone else because they, not you, had the right colored coins for it, can be annoying. That said, there is a pleasant symmetry to this game that make its challenges and frustrating drawbacks, not only bearable, but pleasant. Nice pieces, colorful layouts.   Straddles the line between a serious gamer's game and one that your mother-in-law (random example) could pick up easily and enjoy. Levels, complexities and subtleties emerge with repeated play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
In Alhambra, you purchase tiles to build your palace compound on your player mat.  Each type of tile (tower, fountain, etc) scores, but only if you have a majority of that tile type in your palace, compared with other players.  There are, however, two catches.  First most tiles have a segment of wall on them, and the tile has to be placed in a defined orientation.  This is pretty cool, as you may want a tower that's for sale, but the wall placement makes it useless for you, at least in the short run. Secondly (and most annoyingly) there are four types of currency in various denominations that come off the stack randomly, and four building tiles that are placed next to a symbol of the currency type that can be used to buy it.  So often, you can be left to draw small denominations and watch the next person get large denominations.  And if you do get into good money, it may be the wrong currency type to help you get the tile you need.  So you're triply victimized by the tile coming off the stack randomly, being plunked  on the next available currency type (not randomly, but quite beyond your control), and by the currency type and denomination coming randomly into your hand.  It's way too much to chance when the main scoring features require advance planning and because it's hard to adapt quickly to changing situations.

RATING: 7
Wonderful game with different kinds of set collection. You have to collect sets of different buildings to score victory points. In order to buy these buildings you have to collect sets of different currency. There's also a great tile placement mechanic. The buildings have to be placed in your Alhambra. Some buildings have walls, which score you extra victory points, but can limit your future expansion as well.
I like getting an extra turn by paying exact cash.
It's best with 3-4 players and usually doesn't last much longer than an hour, and that's an hour well spent,

I don't own this game and I'm quite interested in Granada, which adds a few more interesting aspects. The tiles are two-sided and can be flipped by paying for it. Last but not least: scoring is variable, based on the amount of buildings there are of that colour in each players Alhambra, instead of a fixed number per scoring round.

RATING: 6
Played it once in 6-player mode. I imagine it's vastly different with fewer players. It's sort of a cross between Ticket to Ride and Carcassonne. You collect cash in particular colours to buy buildings, and you place those building tiles according to certain rules (i.e. open space cannot be built against walls). Each building is part of a colour group and is scored according to the player(s) with the most buildings of that colour.

Scoring is a nightmare, especially with 6 players. Three scoring rounds (sometimes with prizes for 2nd and 3rd place) * 6 players * (6 colours + plus walls).

RATING: 6
It's a tile-laying/auction game. Currency comes in 4 colors. 4 tiles are randomly put on market, 1 for each currency. The tiles come in a variety of colors, and represent various parts of the palace; some tiles have wall sections on the edge. Players are dealt a random mix of money worth at least 20 ducats, and 4 money cards are on display. 2 scoring cards are mixed into the deck (shuffled into the 2nd and 4th fifths of the money deck). On your turn you may buy a tile or take cash (1 card, or several cards summing to <= 5). If you buy a tile and pay exact change, you get to go again. The tiles you buy are added to your palace (following placement rules) or go to your reserve (you may use a later turn to place a tile from your reserve into your palace). At the end of your turn, any blank spots in the market are replenished (game ends if you cannot), as are spots in the money display (if deck runs out, shuffle the discards). When the 2 scoring cards come up, and again at the end of the game, you score based on #tiles of each color in each player's palace; each color is worth different points, and value increases each scoring round. In addition, each scoring you get 1 point per segment of your longest contiguous wall. High score wins.

Best with 2 or 3, I think. Gets too random with 5 or 6, since few/none of the tiles on display will still be there on your turn! O Zoo Le Mio is a much better tile-laying auction game. Palazzo has some similar features, but is also much better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
A gateway-weight game with a nifty little mechanic.  In this game players take turns either taking money from a market of 4 choices or buying a building with their collected money and adding it to their city tableau.

The nifty mechanic I am referring to is that the money comes in 4 different colors and the buildings are bought with 4 different colors of money.  Also, you can overpay for a building but if you pay with exact change you get an additional action, obviously this can be very powerful.  Once a building is bought it is added to your city and each building tile also has walls that need to properly connect to fit in your city.  The buildings themselves come in 6 different types and you are scored based on majorities in these types.

It's a neat mechanic and this is a fine game but I've moved past this weight of game for the most part (and there are gateways I prefer over this anyway like Ticket to Ride and Dominion) and typically look for deeper experiences these days.

RATING: 9
Solid 8 -- may go up with more plays

May be prone to analysis paralysis with some players because of the number of things you are trying to watch and accomplish simultaneously.  The 1 action per turn except under some circumstances keeps the decision making very tense.

The two player varient is just as fun and solid as playing with more--maybe even better since the pace is quicker.  We've played with 2,3 and 4 now.  Not sure how the game might seem with 6--especially inexperienced players--maybe too slow?

-------

5 years after these initial comments, we pulled Alhambra off the shelf--just plain vanilla Alhambra, and you know, the game really holds up!  Compares very favorably with current games, and was just a fun little game to play.  It shines mainly in the 2 to 4 player range, with perhaps the 3 player game being the sweet spot--I would never play more than 4 players though because it ruins your ability to plan downstream and turns the game to purely tactical.  There is a healthy dose of luck in the tile draws as well as the money flop, but it in no way sets the game, most of the game is truly determined by strategic plans altered by new tactical development.

Considering its longevity, I am adjusting our rating of 8 up to 9.  If you dont have this game it is definitely worth keeping on your shelf--obviously for years!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
[u]Key Words:[/u] Tile-laying - Light - Luck-dependant

[u]Summarized Opinion:[/u] An uninteresting tile-laying game with no compelling decisions to be made, decided by luck of the draw.

[u]My Rating Explained:[/u] Bad. Likely won't play again.

[u]Verbose Assessment:[/u]

I've had two brushes with Alhambra. The first time was a few years back, all I remember is that I didn't like it. The second time was this year, which confirmed my feelings about the game and reminded me of the reasons.

The problem I have with Alhambra is that there are simply not enough compelling decisions to be made to be interesting, and that your actions have little impact on the outcome of the game.

In your turn, you either take money or buy something, providing you have enough money of the correct currency. If there's a nice tile up for sale and you happen to have the money to buy it, good for you. But most of the time, it's hard to plan on this to happen.

So what the games boils down to is taking what's good now, or hoping that something good will turn up by the time your turn rolls around again.

There are no interesting choices to be made about what to buy - some colors are always better than others, and adding more of the same is always better.

Buying something you cannot use right away seems not to be a good idea, so that's a slim chance of some strategy nipped in the bud. The spatial aspect of actually building your Alhambra is obvious, hence not interesting either.

So in the end, there's just not much game left for a gamer to chew on.

RATING: 8
Tile-placing game that's both very simple to understand but also provides an adequate amount of strategy. The aim of the game is to build your own version of Alhambra by placing tiles representing different types of buildings. Despite there being only three actions to choose from each turn, there's still a fair bit of decision-making required as players have to work out how best to place their tiles. Turns are really quick to perform ensuring that the game maintains a great pace. Artwork and components are typical Euro-fare i.e. a bit bland, but the game seems to blend gameplay with the theme very well indeed.

RATING: 7
A solid gateway game. It isn't my favorite, but it is easy to pick up and plays really smoothly. There are some interesting decisions about whether to pick up a tile that you might have to overpay for or push your luck and hope that you can pick up the cards to pay with exact change to get the bonus action (before someone else takes the tile you want). 

In my experience the place for reserving tiles and then switching tiles in and out from the reserve to your Alhambra doesn't really get utilized. However, this might just be because I haven't played the game enough to see how that reserve can be helpfully incorporated into a strategy.

Update: For a light game, I still prefer Carcassonne and a few others. I also prefer Palazzo, which has a few similarities. [b]Player Count Verdict: 2-4[/b]

Suitability for Travel:

I have a 1 to 5 scale for four categories (1 is worst, 5 is best) in order of importance:

Portability (the less luggage space the better) - 3
Footprint (the less table space when playing the better) - 2
Scalability (the wider range of player counts the better) - 4
Learnability (the easier to teach non-gamers the better) - 4


Overall - 3

RATING: 4
This game was rather unimpressive at first, but it grows on me (and not only me) as I keep playing it. 
It has good mechanics that force you to make the best possible decision every round and reward you in the end for your total performance.

What my groups think of it:

1) My girlfriend was initially bored from the uninspiring concept, but it's grown on her too especially when played with other couples that usually like it. I think the game plays it's best in this kind of groups, aka mixed with 4 or 6 players.

2) My main group (average male gamers) prefers pretty much every other game in my collection (ok, every other above monopoly/risk etc). No one was even decently enthusiastic about it after a couple of plays. They find the strategy not deep enough and the interaction poor at best. But they've not trashed it yet. 
Update: After a long time, it's also grown on a player of this group, who now casually asks to play this game. Alhambra spreads like a disease!

3) My parents liked this game from the start. They think it is very relaxing to play.

The game plays differently but equally well as you increase the number of players. With fewer players, it's more about timing your buys. With more players, it's more about card(money) management. 

Update: Granada has kicked this game low.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
In the game you're buying tiles to build your city. There's three scoring periods, the first two are semi-random but the third is at the end of the game. The points for these scoring periods increases over the course of the game. Additionally, you get points for every segment in your longest contiguous exterior wall at the scoring period.

In order to buy tiles, you need money. There's a central card row where you can take money in lieu of buying a tile. Money comes in different colors and each color is tied to one of the markets. You have to pay the correct color for the tile in that market. You can either take cards that total up to 5 or a single card equal to or higher than 5. When you buy a tile, if you pay the exact cost, you can take another action.

That's the game. It's a little luck dependent both in whether the appropriate color money comes out, or if the tile you want/need comes out at the right time in the right spot, but it's still fun nonetheless.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Alhambra mixes market buying and tile placement into an interesting mix of elements.  Each turn, you have the option of taking money from the money market (you're allowed to choose one "money" card out of the four available or multiple cards that add up to five or less), using your "money" cards to buy a city tile (there are four available, with different costs), or rearrange your tiles within your city (because there are some very simple placement rules for where you can place your tiles within your city, a la Carcassonne).  That's pretty much the entire game.

There are three scoring rounds throughout the game where you compare your city to other players and are awarded points for having lots of particular types of districts (each tile in your city is a district) and a big wall along the outside of your district (most tiles have a "wall" along their edge).

Right now, Alhambra may be the most popular game in our game group and is the clear favorite of one of the female members of our group.  It has been pulled out at every single gaming session we've had recently.

I'm not sure how it will hold up to a ton of plays.  Although each turn you're given a choice of four options from the "tile" market and four choices from the "money" market, the random drawing of each provides two fairly strong sources of randomness into the game that are largely outside the player's control.  Usually, when a game has a strong dose of random, I tend to get tired of it more quickly.

I would recommend Alhambra to anyone who really enjoys the tile placement elements of Carcassonne.  Alhambra retains the joy of drawing random tiles and placing them to build a larger structure, but introduces a "market" element to, in my opinion, improve on the random "draw one, then place it" aspect of tile placement in Carcassonne.

RATING: N/A
In Alhambra, players are acquiring buildings to be placed within their Alhambra complex. On a player's turn, a player may 1) take money from the open money market, 2) purchase a building from the building market and either place it in his Alhambra or reserve, or 3) engage in construction and re-construction projects with buildings that have been placed in the player's Alhambra or reserve.

2-5 (best 3)

Tile placement, set collection, city building

RATING: 6
Poster child for the lighter SDJ winners that are appropriate for family gaming with a little bit of strategy.  I didn't really see much innovative here, which I was a little disappointed in.  The city building aspect was disappointingly like Carcassonne, and the picking up money aspect was like any of a number of designs, most notably Alan Moon designs like Union Pacific or Elfenland.  The one unique thing about the game was the exact change necessity, which is intriguing, but not enough to set the game apart on its own.  Furthermore, I'm kind of worried that it mostly leads to a luck-heavy experience where having the right currency amounts for the cards will determine the winner.  Doesn't really seem like there's much of a learning curve here.  After your first game, you know the general strategy.  From there, the decisions are largely tactical.

RATING: N/A
Dirk Henn; Alhambra is the latest update to the stock market game Stimmt So!, only it has been completely re-themed with a Moorish theme and has an additional tile-laying component. On a player's turn, they can do one of the following actions: 1. Draw one or several currency cards. 2. Buy a tile from the market by playing any number of currency cards whose value equals or exceeds the number on the tile (no change is given) in the appropriate currency. Exactly matching the tile value gives the player an additional action. At the end of the turn the tiles must be added to the Alhambra or placed on the player's reserve board. 3. Alhambra construction. The player may move one tile from the reserve board to the Alhambra, from the Alhambra to the reserve board, or exchange the exact position of one tile in the Alhambra and one in the reserve board. When the each scoring card appears, the game is immediately paused and the appropriate round is scored. After scoring buildings, each player then scores the longest wall in their Alhambra. The third and final scoring is played when there are not enough building tiles available to refill all markets on the building market board. The winner is the player with the highest number of points. Expanded by: The Vizier's Favor, The City Gates, The Thief's Turn, The Treasure Chamber

RATING: 8
------------------------------
NOTICE : Due to my poor spoken & written English, the rest of my comments will be written in French only but you can read my profile for more informations about the kind of games I prefer and how I rated them.
------------------------------

►ÉDITION : Queen games, multilingue, 2007.
Éditeur, nb joueurs : 2 à 6 joueurs.
Éditeur, durée : 0h45 à 1h00/partie.
Éditeur, âge : 8 ans et plus.

►PUBLIC(S) QUE JE RECOMMANDE:
☺ Jeu tactique (plus d’éléments aléatoires et/ou de hasard raisonné).
® Je crains que son allure "sobre" soit peu attrayante pour les jeunes.

►JOUEURS, NOMBRE(S) QUE JE RECOMMANDE:
# Meilleur : 3
# Recommandé : 4
# Non-recommandé : 5, 6
# Non-essayé : 2
5 ou 6 joueurs : pas essayé mais je doute que cette(ces) configuration(s) soi(en)t vraiment intéressante(s). J'ai l'impression que le temps d'attente entre les tours sera trop long considérant qu’il est presqu’impossible de planifier quoique ce soit avant son tour.
2 joueurs : pas essayé car je n’ai pas d’intérêt pour les configurations requérant un joueur virtuel.

►COMMENTAIRE(S) ABRÉGÉ(S):
± THÈME : plutôt plaqué; mais agrémente le jeu.
+ Icônes : sont faciles à comprendre ou à mémoriser.

►REMARQUE(S) PERSONNELLE(S):
Dès mon 1e essai, ce jeu a soulevé mon intérêt malgré que j’avais trouvé qu'il lui manquait un petit "je-ne-sais-quoi". Cependant, puisqu'il a l'avantage d'offrir une panoplie d'extensions, je l'ai personnalisé à mon goût.

►VARIANTE(S) UTILISÉE(S):
Δ MAISON : je n'ai pas essayé cette variante mais au lieu de mettre les tuiles « Édifice » dans le sac de pioche, j'envisage de les mettre en piles, faces cachées, près du plateau « Chantiers » afin que tous les joueurs puissent mieux prévoir la fin de partie et faire leurs dernières actions en conséquence.

►EXTENSION(S) ESSAYÉE(S): 
… voir chaque extension pour plus de détails.
& « 1: La faveur du vizir » en partie : « Bureaux de change »;
& « 3: L'heure des voleurs » en partie : « Les voleurs »;
& « 4: La chambre au trésor du calife » en partie : « Les architectes »;
& « Les édifices magiques »: Oui.
& Je n'ai jamais essayé l'(les) autre(s) module(s)/extension(s) parce qu’il(s) n’a(ont) pas assez soulevé mon intérêt pour me convaincre de le faire.
