RATING: 7
A fairly simple game that combines set collection, card drafting and some tile laying. It's similar to Carcassonne, except that it has a currency system which allows you to select tiles to buy instead of drawing them at random. The market also has an interesting mechanic that permits players to take extra actions during their turn if they can pay for their purchases with exact change. It's a weird rule, but its presence adds strategy and a few more difficult decisions to the game's rather simple tile draft.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Solid introductory game, not dense. Cultivate your strategy (plainly) and roll with what the deck throws your way. Got my father playing, and in-laws too. Very instructive to see what real-estate acquisition reveals about character.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
There's nothing really wrong with this game, I don't think. Mechanically, everything is fairly sound; the only complaint I have is that, like Vegas Showdown, it's a game that offers you many choices but the means to do few of them, so it becomes a very tactical game masquerading as a strategic one. But, while I'm not crazy about VS, I at least had fun playing that. I generally like Euros, and while some have gotten stale for me quickly (Thurn & Taxis), this is the first one I've played where I just felt bored, and like I was just passing time rather than having fun. And a SdJ winner to boot! I guess I just didn't find the decisions particularly interesting. To compare it to VS again, you had a pretty good idea of what was going to happen if you bought or didn't buy a premium tile because of the reference card. In Alhambra, there are so many tiles that you really don't have a lot of basis for predicting what will come out next. Instead of "do I want this tile, or do I want to wait to get the next one that will come out, which has an X% chance of being better for me?", it just turns into "do I want this tile?", and the different forms of currency mean that, even if you did memorize them all and figure out exactly which ones you needed, there's no guarantee you'd actually be able to pay for it. I don't know. I thought I would like this game a lot, and was very disappointed.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 1
{ P - [3] 4 5 }

I half-heartedly bracketed '3' players because with reasonable memorization you can know precisely what income cards both your opponents have and thus what they are able to purchase exactly, though this "perk" is really just a pyrrhic victory considering the rote memorization substitutes one dull experience with another. Conversely, playing with five the game is pure agony and little more than collecting two colors, walls and hoping the folks going right before you flip the tiles you need in the colors you're collecting. Random tile replacement, random money replacement, random distribution of leftover tiles, interim scoring at random times. Arrgh.

RATING: 7
Alhambra has relatively interesting game mechanics. The choosing of currency cards and building market ensure high replayability. The scoring of connected walls also gives players the unique challenge of constructing an Alhambra that maximises its length.

However, the luck component of it can be pretty "in your face". This is with reference to which currency cards and building tiles turn up on the market, as well as what building tiles are given to Dirk if it happens to be a 2 player game. It sometimes gives players the feeling of loss of control.

Spiel de Jahres - dare to dream.

Man, I'm giving out a lot of 7s and 7.5s today.

I'm going out on a limb here, but this has to be a gateway to Eurogaming.  I played it once and really enjoyed it.  If I see it on sale and have some free cash to blow, I'll probably pick it up someday.

RATING: 6.5
It's okay, but like many other games from the early 2000's, is starting to show its age. I still like the monetary aspects of multiple currencies and the advantages of exact change, but if I were interested in a city-building (err... building-building?), there are better options. If someone were excited to play there wouldn't be too much arm-twisting, but it wouldn't be my first suggestion.

RATING: 7
Not bad, but not as good as expected. I usually don't mind when there's some luck in a game, but not when it lasts more than a hour. In most of the games I played, the winner was the player who managed to buy many buildings at the right price (having the right card at the right moment). I find that the game plays by itself : you take that tile at the right price even if you don't need it. Using the Reserve is too penalizing and it's hard to make good use of it. There's nothing to do whhen waiting for your turn. It's hard to plan ahead with more than 3 players because the board changes drastically. Oh well... I love the design of the box and game components.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
